SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Opposition does not oppose the general nature of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill 1984 and the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1984, but at the Committee stage will be proposing certain amendments to them. The Bills have been debated in detail in the House of Representatives. Their purpose has been outlined in the second reading speech of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh). Therefore, I do not see that it is necessary to take up the time of the Senate by going through the Bills again, other than to say that they are basically amendments and some alterations to government programs-programs introduced by the former Government, including in particular the extremely beneficial and widely acclaimed Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act. That Act brought about a major project for the development of roads in Australia in the period leading up to the bicentenary in 1988 by the addition of an extra excise on fuel, which was to be applied for the purpose of this program.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern, to which reference will be made during the Committee stage, is that that excise has now been increased by the automatic increases introduced by the Government which will take place in February and August each year. The increases under the automatic indexation of the excise raised under the Act are not being passed on for the purposes of the Act. That is a matter of considerable concern to the Opposition. We believe that fairness requires that the purpose of the raising of the levy be recognised and that any increase in the amount of the levy be used for the same purpose as that for which the levy was designed. To use it in any other way is just a sneaky roundabout method of increasing government revenue by misusing the increased revenue in a way other than for the purposes for which it was designed in the original legislation by the previous Government, which was supported by the whole of the Parliament.

The other area of concern is the changes made to the form of tendering. Again, during the Committee stage, I shall be referring to that matter in more detail. I do not wish to take up the Senate's time by going through matters which are not disputed. I indicate that we shall support the second reading of the Bill but in Committee I shall propose two amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, we are debating cognately the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill 1984 and the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1984. The purpose of these Bills is to amend three areas of the original Acts to allow for smoother running of the Australian bicentennial road development program. These areas deal with tendering and State expenditure on roads and urban public transport systems. As the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) pointed out in his second reading speech, although we supported the general thrust and objectives of the bicentennial road program when it was introduced by the former Government, we expressed concern about certain aspects of the legislation, in particular, the provision which required that all construction work on national urban arterial and rural arterial roads must go to tender. I will come to that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody could disagree with the fact that when we came to government Australia's road system was amongst the worst in the world. Years of neglect by successive Liberal governments had reduced many of our national highways to potholes, gravel tracks, et cetera. It was certainly no coincidence that the Fraser Government finally decided to act positively in this area in an election year. It finally realised that our roads were the laughing stock of the developed world. In recognition of the worthiness and importance of the Australian bicentennial road development program, on coming to government we decided to continue the program and will be providing an estimated $2,500m for roads between now and 1988-89. In fact in our first Budget we provided for a 45 per cent increase in total road grants which included, of course, the jobs on local roads scheme.

As I mentioned earlier when the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act was introduced by the former Government the Australian Labor Party supported the general objectives of the program. However, it was concerned about some of the provisions in the legislation and undertook to review them when coming to Government. Accordingly, discussions were held with various parties, including State and local governments, industry spokesmen and relevant unions. It was out of this process of consultation that three areas requiring change were identified. The amendments contained in this Bill will go a long way to improving the operation of the ABRD program. The Bill introduces some flexibility into the requirement that tender must be called by the States for all works associated with national and arterial projects. The Bill allows the Minister to agree, upon request by a State, to an exemption from the requirement to call tenders for particular works where the Minister is satisfied that specific circumstances apply.

As the Minister said in his second reading speech the Government is satisfied with the general principle of calling tenders for road construction. However, we recognise that there needs to be greater flexibility to cover situations where the process of calling tenders is either impracticable or simply not cost effective. Therefore an exemption to tendering will be granted when a State can demonstrate that there is an emergency requirement for the works to be performed , or when the works are of such a minor nature that calling tenders would involve undue additional cost, or when it is not practical to prepare adequate tender specifications for the works, or when the works are of such a kind that competitive tenders are unlikely to be received, or when the works involve adjustments to utility services which would normally be undertaken by a government department, a government authority or a corporation not primarily responsible for the construction of roads, or when the performance of the work under contract would cause unavoidable retrenchments or inefficiency in the deployment of a substantial number of State or local government road construction employees.

I now turn briefly to the other two amendments contained in this Bill. The second aspect of this Bill relates to the existing requirement that States must maintain expenditure in real terms during the life of the ABRD program. The amended legislation will allow States to carry over excess expenditure to the following year in a way which will ease the strain and assist the States in maintaining the levels of real spending agreed to. The present legislation penalises States which do not reach the required level of expenditure in a given year by forcing them to make up the deficit in the following year but it does not allow them to carry over any excesses. This amendment merely allows the States to gain any benefits accrued from exceeding this expenditure requirement in any one year. This new flexibility is sensible and practicable and will allow the States to plan ahead in a way that suits their available resources and priorities. The final area of amendment relates to the existing requirement that where a State proposes that part of its urban road allocation be directed to urban public transport capital works projects it must maintain, in real terms, its own capital expenditure on public transport. Again this penalises those States which have made the decision to use a portion of their funds to upgrade their public transport systems. This Bill removes the requirement that the real level of expenditure on public transport be maintained where this option is taken up.

As a result of this amendment the States will now be able to elect to upgrade their public transport systems without the fear of receiving a penalty for doing so. In other words the States will no longer be disadvantaged by the reasonable use of those funds. The amendments being introduced by the Government will ensure maximum efficiency and cost effectiveness of the ABRD program. Unlike previous administrations this Government is committed to improving and upgrading Australia's road networks. As I have stated, the total allocation of Commonwealth funds for road works in 1983-84 is 45 per cent above that expended in 1982-83, which is a far cry from the Fraser years when we saw a reduction in real terms of 23 per cent between 1975-76 and 1981-82. In fact the Hawke Labor Government has done more to improve Australia's roads in just 12 months than the Fraser Government did in seven years in office.

As a South Australian senator I am particularly pleased to see substantial progress being made on the sealing of the Port Augusta-Alice Springs road and the upgrading of the Duke's Highway in South Australia, the main road link between Adelaide and Melbourne. Wherever one drives in South Australia at the moment, whether it be in the country or in the Adelaide metropolitan area, one can see progress being made. These improvements will do much to save vehicle running costs, cut travelling time and above all save many lives. Quite a lot has been said recently about the dangers of drink driving but it is a fact that over the Easter break most road deaths occurred in the country and I am sure the state of our country roads and interstate highways had something to do with that tragic loss of life. If we can save even just a handful of lives by providing safe roads we will have achieved something worth while.

These Bills are another fine example of consensus and consultation at work in the Australian community under the present Government. They were drafted after discussions and agreement between the various interested parties and they will provide for the smoother running of a very important Government program. This Government has achieved a considerable amount in a short time. We have the housing industry going again, employment levels are rising, the rate of inflation is falling, the level of industrial disputation is at an all time low, tourism is starting to flourish and through our transport policies we are reconstructing Australia's roadways. I am pleased to commend these Bills to all honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats first pay a tribute to the Fraser Government for its initiative in the introduction of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund. This initiative is to be applauded and will benefit Australians right across this nation for many years to come. It is a very worthy activity which has been undertaken under the auspices of the bicentennial objectives. One of the things that has been very good in this debate and in the introduction of the fund has been the bipartisan approach by the Government and the Opposition, first of all to the necessity for such a fund in this vast nation of ours and, secondly, to the broad modus operandi of the fund.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Bill before us today will continue with that broad consensus although there are a couple of areas where there may be minor disagreement. The overall program is therefore strongly supported by the Australian Democrats. We need to have a close look at this legislation in that amendments are proposed to the original Act which change the thrust of the funding and the system of getting the work done. This could disadvantage not just contractors but employment in certain parts of the Australian economy. The proposal in the Bill to change the system of tendering is a retrograde step. I believe that the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) already has enough powers to enable him and the State governments virtually to ignore any tenderer's submission. That means that if he wished he could use the facilities of a statutory body, whether it be State or local government, to carry out the relevant road works and leave the private contractors on the side-line. That has always been the case. In fact , I am aware of situations where contractors around Australia have felt disadvantaged by that system. Despite that, they have learned to live with it and there is a degree of compliance by all parties, including the statutory bodies, with the system as it exists.

I believe that the changes that are proposed in this legislation to enable a State government to make recommendations to the Federal Minister for the tendering system to be put aside will create uncertainty in the contracting industry, cause dissension between private and statutory bodies and will give the appearance, if not the fact, of statutory bodies having a distinct advantage over and above the advantages they already have. It needs to be remembered that statutory bodies already have advantages over private contractors: They are not taxed and they do not need to provide a profit. Those are quite substantial advantages. I believe in this free economy it is important that we recognise that a free enterprise system needs to have opportunities right across the board for private enterprise to get into the substantial, significant contract work that is being done, whether it be funded by government or by private enterprise. So the Australian Democrats are not inclined to support that aspect of the legislation as it stands at the moment.

I just remind the Senate that, if the Government were willing to live with the existing provisions, the Minister virtually has the same powers in any case. He can still choose a tender on grounds other than cost. In essence, the six criteria that are set out in the Bill can be used right at this moment. But under the existing system before giving work to a statutory body-a State or local government body-the Minister must receive and must be aware of all of the options. If he refuses to call for tenders under certain circumstances he will not have all the options in front of him. As I see it, that really is a critical element because it means that the State Government may have a preconception and the Federal Minister would be unaware of some of the alternatives that could have been available.

The whole principle of tendering gives us the advantage of a meaningful measure of performance and accountability at the end of a job. I believe that is a very vital ingredient in a process such as this where the work not only has to be done to the satisfaction of the person doing the job but also has to be done to the satisfaction of those who are setting down the criteria and who have to measure against those criteria at the end of the contract. I believe under a tendering system the Government can achieve the greatest output for the dollar spent. I think that that is a vital principle that this Government-and any government-needs to take on board. The whole principle of tendering is aimed at achieving the objective.

The other aspect, which I am sure the Government is aware of but which perhaps it needs to be reminded about, is that the tendering system allows the Government to draw on a larger pool of resources. Some of these resources may be more easily mobilised than those of the statutory bodies, may give better utilisation of resources that are available in a particular area or for a particular job. That will not always be the situation if one gives some priority or preference to the State or local government bodies.

If the government of that particular State or Territory and the Government of Australia decided in their wisdom that they want to ignore certain advantages that are available by accepting the tender of a private contractor, it is still within their power under the existing legislation to ignore those advantages. What we are saying is that it is important for the sake of the Australian economy and the industry to keep the tender system going. I think that the effect on the industry could be quite salutary if this Bill is passed in its present form. I think that there would be an increasing degree of uncertainty in the industry. At the moment the industry has blossomed, comparatively, since the original introduction of the bicentennial road development trust and all that goes with it. I believe it would be a very sad day for that industry and for Australia if uncertainty came about as a result of a change in the tendering system.

In this area we are not talking about big business. In the majority of cases we are talking about relatively small private enterprises-small when compared with multinationals which seem to get favoured treatment from governments of all political colours. In this area we are talking about ensuring that there is a degree of competitiveness and a degree of entree, of continuing access, to this growth area. Private contractors around Australia are looking to this Parliament to protect their interests as this legislation goes through. It ensures the continuing stimulation of those small businesses.

I believe that the Opposition, in general-that certainly includes the Australian Democrats-is solidly in support of the continuing thrust of the ABRD Trust Fund and all that goes with it. I will speak a little later to an amendment which I understand is being moved by the Opposition. Suffice to say at this stage that the Democrats are delighted that the Government is continuing the impetus which was established by the previous Government in this road development drive for Australia; one of Australia's great areas of need simply because of the size of the continent and the desperate need for improved communications and transport facilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in the debate on the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill 1984 and the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1984. This legislation deals principally with three matters: Firstly, changes to the tendering arrangements in the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act and the Roads Grants Act; secondly, the effort required by State governments on their road programs; and, thirdly, the efforts required of State governments to maintain their public transport programs. A fourth matter is very much involved in the overall situation and that is the Government's intention to index the fuel levy. Honourable senators and people in Australia will realise that this levy was established in 1982 after a good deal of discussion between the Government, industry and motorists' organisations. A one cent levy and then a two cent levy on motor spirit and automotive distillate was agreed upon, on the condition that all funds raised through the levy would be used on the roads program.

SPEECH.PARA: This bicentennial road development program goes back several years. It was first proposed by the Hon. Ralph Hunt. I believe that this is one of the most important projects that has been introduced into parliament for years. Mr Hunt is to be commended for introducing this scheme a few years ago. Senator Jack Evans spoke about this program to some extent when he commended the Fraser Government for having brought it forward. The Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund was to give some impetus to the construction of roads throughout Australia, not only along the eastern coast which, over the years, has been relatively well looked after, but also through the outback. Over the years only some funds have been given to these most important projects. People of the outback believe that this program is very important to them.

I commend the previous Government for having brought about the beef road program some years ago. The beef road program developed arterial roads throughout the outback that could be looked upon not only as beef roads but also developmental roads. These roads in the Northern Territory, in other parts of the outback and in various States have proved most important not just in the development of the pastoral industry. Certainly we see that they have played a major part in the development of the mining industry at Jabiru and places. They have also given a tremendous boost to the tourist industry in the Northern Territory and the whole of Australia. This has allowed Australians really to go outback in some reasonable comfort to see the attractions of this country. I think the beef road program was a most successful project. It has meant much to Australia and very much to the people who live in the outback.

Road development is now to be continued with this bicentennial road program. The purpose of this program is to improve roads throughout the nation, to bring them up to a national level. Some people have said that it will bring about a black ribbon of bitumen not only around the perimeter of Australia but also through the outback. Many projects have been planned-others are on the drafting board-for roads to be brought up to a national standard by 1988. It was felt that, because of the financial demands that would be made on the Government, extra funds would have to be raised to finance this bicentennial program. Motorists in Australia were called on to participate. As I have indicated, they were called on to participate by paying a one cent levy and then a two cent levy for every litre of petrol that they purchased. The two cents levy was to go into this fund to upgrade national roads. This has come about.

The point that concerns not only honourable senators on this side of the House but also motorists in Australia-every person who has been interested in this project and the raising of the levy to fund this project has been concerned-is that the indexation of this fuel levy, which has been introduced by this Government, brings about an increase in funds raised from Australian motorists of something like $491m this financial year. In anyone's lot that is a considerable amount of money. Yet the most incredible thing about this situation is that while the two cents levy is being raised for the singular purpose of upgrading national roads the Australian motorist has to pay one decimal point more through indexation. This will raise some $491 a year. As I understand it- this has not been contradicted by the Government-that money is not going into the national road scheme even though that was its purpose and that is what it was all about. It means that this extra tax of $491m that is being raised by the Federal Government is not going into the national road scheme as it should be under the arrangements for the project. Instead it will go into Consolidated Revenue for the Government to use for some other purpose. I ask: Is this action correct?

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the difference between that and misappropriation?

—That was a very fine point made by Senator Rae. Perhaps it is legal, and that is okay. Regardless of whether it is legal, morally it is a misappropriation of funds from the Australian motorist. Those funds are going into some other quarter. I wonder where the funds are going. I note that the Federal Government is now endeavouring to bring about taxation allowances in the next Budget. Is this the way the Federal Government will raise the money? Is the Federal Government going to raise it by taxing the Australian motorist and then giving it back in a minor degree through taxation allowances? As Senator Rae said, in anyone's view this is a misappropriation of funds. In our view it certainly is.

SPEECH.PARA: I will return now briefly to the Northern Territory situation and the levy. There are long distances, not only in the Territory but in the outback generally , to be travelled by people. Therefore, the people of the outback have to travel more than the city dwellers. When one looks at the situation in that manner it can be seen that the people in the outback really contribute more to the levy than do city dwellers. Again, I say outback people are being touched by this indexation. Another matter concerns me too. I refer to the money allocated last year by the Federal Government for Northern Territory contracts but which has been withheld by the Federal Government until now. I refer to a letter of 27 April which I received from the Minister for Transport, Mr Peter Morris, in which he said:

I have pleasure in advising you that I have approved further road projects for the Northern Territory for funding under the Roads Grants Act 1981 and the Australian Bicentennial Road Development (ABRD) Program.
The Minister continued:
The projects, two of which will be funded under the Road Grants Act 1981 and three under the ABRD Program, provide for reconstruction and general upgrading of the Stuart Highway.

The Minister then gave various details of the program worth some $17,097,000 covering five contracts. In the Minister's letter he referred to the $16.8m project approval for the Stuart Highway. In the Press release attached to the letter it is stated that the project approval follows his undertaking in Parliament earlier this month to have an officer from the Department of Transport evaluate the works proposed by the Northern Territory Government. The Minister is quoted as saying:
In view of earlier assertions by the NT Government, I needed to satisfy myself that the projects were necessary.

That is an unusual statement for a Federal Minister to make regarding another government, even though it is one of different political views. I think that when one considers the situation it can be seen as an unnecessary slur on a Territory government well recognised for its efforts to upgrade the quality of life of the people of the outback. That can be proved quite conclusively. When I talk about the quality of life, one of those qualities of course concerns reasonable roads so that people in the outback can travel in reasonable comfort. To assert that it is necessary to send an officer to check on that Government I think is more than a slur, it is an insult, particularly when one considers the work that has been carried out by the Northern Territory Government.

If it were the case that the Northern Territory Government was not doing its job for the people of the outback in developing road programs what would we expect? We would expect that in an election such a government would be removed from the scene. Has that Government been removed? It has not. In the last election the people of the Northern Territory voted the Government in with 19 seats compared with six seats for the Opposition. This is the judgment of the people who have to use such facilities. The Northern Territory Government is doing the right thing by the people of the outback. However the Federal Minister for Transport has the audacity to send a person to the Northern Territory to see whether he is satisfied with what the Northern Territory Government is doing. I notice too that a Minister in this chamber yesterday made some very derogatory remarks about the upgrading of the Stuart Highway in the Northern Territory. The remarks were to the effect that there seemed to be some move within the Northern Territory by the Chief Minister to go back on his word and change his ideas. I find that very difficult to understand, especially when one peruses the correspondence and messages and sees the actions that have taken place over the last few months.

I refer to a letter of 21 March to the Federal Minister for Transport, Peter Morris, from the Minister for Transport and Works in the Northern Territory who has had a most difficult job because funds have been withheld for months. Why were they withheld? The funds were withhold as a result of the Hill Independent Economic Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory report. That report was presented to the Federal Government. Honourable senators might remember that this Mr Hill was the Executive Director of the State Rail Authority of New South Wales. It was his job to review the transport requirements relating to the building of the rail link from Alice Springs to Darwin. Funds for this project have been refused by the Federal Government even though it was an election promise. The report also looked at the necessity for road upgrading. I have referred to the rail link previously and I am not going along that track now because we are talking about the motorist.

It was said in the Hill report that the upgrading of the Stuart Highway was not particularly necessary. Prior to that report it was said that if the Northern Territory Government and people wanted the rail link perhaps they would agree to moneys allocated to upgrading the Stuart Highway being applied to the construction of the railway. Of course, that never came about. It was said then that there was a real case for both the road and rail link and that the funding of the road should not be interrupted. Several contracts were going to tender at that time and, to this week, money for tenders that had been called for and let in good faith has been withheld. The contractor now finds that he cannot start work because there are no funds. The Hon. Jim Robertson, the Northern Territory Minister for Transport and Works, said in one letter:

You will recall that I telexed you on 25 February expressing my concern over deferral of approval for new works on the Stuart Highway. Deferral of the five projects worth approximately $10m has caused considerable disruption to the construction industry in the Northern Territory and has created significant loss of job opportunities.
Of these five projects, tenders have closed on two and the others are scheduled to close this month.
The letter goes on to indicate what those contracts were. They have been mentioned before so I will not take up the time of the Senate going through that information now. He said also in a telex:
The lowest tenderers . . . are both ready to proceed with the respective works immediately approval is granted.

The deferral of these new projects has resulted in an untenable situation where we can no longer achieve the 83/84 expenditure requirements of the national highway programs with the major effect being reflected on the Australian bicentennial road development program.

It is imperative that the construction of the Stuart Highway proceeds if the objectives of the ABRD program are to be met. As you know the primary objective is to upgrade the nation's road system to a high standard by, or soon after, 1988. Important factors in this aim are the meeting of the growing transportation needs of Australia; the enhancement of safety on our roads; the construction of developmental roads, including those of importance for national tourism.
Tourism is of the utmost importance. He continues:

I would very much appreciate your urgent consideration in expediting approval to these outstanding projects in order that these aims be achieved. Continuity of work and much needed job opportunities in the Territory will also result once these works get under way.
At the very least and as an interim measure I request that the two projects for which acceptable tenders are held be allowed to commence immediately.

After all that-this has been going on for quite some time now-the Minister, as if there is something new about it, as if it is completely off his own bat, having held up funds for most necessary road projects for several months, comes out with a slur on the Northern Territory Government, suggesting that it is not doing its job. It was a most remarkable statement. This is in keeping with the point I made previously on another matter; that is, that the Federal Government is misappropriating funds from the bicentennial road development program.

There are other matters but I will touch on them only very quickly because they have been covered by others. Very briefly, on the matter of tendering, it is my understanding that an amendment is to be moved in an endeavour to have the present situation rectified so that private enterprise, which employs so many people in the field and which means so much to employment, will be responsible for road construction. Surely when one is on a good thing one should stick to it . Why take away something when it is working well and put in its place a scheme that has not been proved? I am not saying that it will not work. I am asking: Why tamper with the existing situation which has proved very conclusively that private enterprise, be it in the cities, along the seaboard or along the highways in the outback, has the ability to carry out what is required? Surely it is in keeping with the character of the bicentennial road development program , which is to be completed by 1988-at least until the Federal Government tampers with it-a program in which all Australian motorists are participating, that private enterprise plays its part.

In conclusion, I find it very disappointing to see an Australian Federal government behaving in such a shoddy manner. The approach adopted in this legislation and in what the Minister for Transport has said is typical of the behaviour of a group of politicians who are in opposition, not in government. I expect much more of a Federal government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION AND COMMONWEALTH DEVELOPMENT BANK

Have these changes had any effect on the performance of these institutions as yet? Secondly , how do the Government and the Minister expect that these changes will alter the role of both of these institutions in the proposed revitalisation of Australian industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Bolkus for his question, which came as something of a surprise to me. But it provides me with an opportunity to say something about the importance which the Government attaches to these two instrumentalities.
—Why are you putting your glasses on?
—I put my glasses on because they help me not to see Senator Lewis when I am answering a question.
—Order! The Minister will answer Senator Bolkus's question.

—Both the Australian Industry Development Corporation and the Commonwealth Development Bank occupy very important places in the Government's industry policy. The changes announced by me last year in relation to both those institutions, particularly the AIDC, have dramatically improved the capacity of those institutions to play an effective part in industrial recovery. In 1983-84 the AIDC's financial performance has been extraordinary. The return on capital and reserves was a record 14 per cent. Net profit was a record $15.3m, up 45 per cent on the previous year. The AIDC was ranked first in profit per employee amongst the top 500 companies in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I was also asked about the Commonwealth Development Bank, which continues to perform a vital role as an important source of finance for business in Australia , particularly small business. In the eight-month period from July 1983 to March 1984 the Bank's lending to business increased by 114 per cent from $22m to $47m over the corresponding period in 1982-83. In the light of that performance record of both institutions it is quite extraordinary that the Opposition of this country proposes to sell these institutions because of some ideological commitment to the sale of the best and brightest examples of Australian public sector initiatives. That quite extraordinary announcement was made by the Opposition a week or so ago. It is the same old, tired, razor gang revisited philosophy which characterised this Opposition when in government. I would have thought it was an extraordinary announcement. In making that announcement about the AIDC and the Commonwealth Development Bank the Opposition said that it would look at a number of other government instrumentalities-with all the charm of a cobra. Over many years the Fraser Government looked at a number of other government instrumentalities and did nothing about them.

Sir Gordon Jackson, Chairman of the AIDC, one of the institutions specifically referred to, in a recent speech said:

Australia is desperately in need of better institutions and processes to facilitate adaptation to change. We are fortunate that the AIDC is over its establishment years and is in good vigorous condition to serve Australia. If it had not been created it would certainly have had to have been invented.

If the Opposition is to make a sensible contribution to the debate on these issues and on the future shape of Australian industry it would be better advised , in the Government's view, not to adopt its current proposals in relation to these two fine institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the papers from which he has quoted.
—The Minister has tabled those papers.

If one looks at the history of this matter and at the performance of this Government when it was in opposition, one finds that the views which we espouse today about this matter are consistent with those which we espoused when we were in opposition. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED KINGDOM ATOMIC TESTS IN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy a question about the United Kingdom atomic tests which took place in Australia two to three decades ago. I am concerned that some people may interpret his public comments, which give the facts to the extent that his Department's records show them, as somehow condoning those tests. Will he assure the Senate that he in no way defends those tests, conducted as they were under the auspices of a government of the political persuasion of our opponents, and that the present Government would not be, and would not have been, involved in allowing any such tests; that, while there may be continuing argument about the extent of damage to personnel directly involved and to others who may have been in the area then or since, the tests did no one any good; and further, that while this Government would have to take responsibility on behalf of its predecessors for any compensation which may be awarded by a court, it is not responsible, nor does it excuse, any lapse that may have occurred in the way in which those tests were conducted with the approval of the Menzies Government. Finally, will he also assure us that he will not permit a similarly conservative UK government to misuse so-called national security arguments to hide information which Australia ought to have?

—I assure the honourable senator that the Australian Government is opposed to the testing of atomic weapons. Indeed, that opposition was made to the French in very forceful terms last year, and continues to be made this year. The Australian Labor Party, when in opposition, of course, has long been opposed either to atmospheric or non-atmospheric testing. If I recall correctly, that opposition dates back at least to the early 1960s and possibly further back. With the knowledge of today, it would be generally agreed that many of the things done by the British-with the full approval of the then Australian Government, of course, as Senator Coates noted-at Maralinga were at best careless and at worst irresponsible. It could even be argued that some of them fitted into that category even at the time that they took place. To be fair to the British, I think it ought to be noted for the record that due to the typically sycophantic Liberal-National Party Government that ruled Australia at the time, the British were virtually begged to come to Australia to conduct those tests. Therefore, any criticism of the UK should be put into that context. In other words, the blame for whatever happened at Maralinga ultimately rests squarely with the then Government of Australia; that is, the sycophantic coalition Government led by Sir Robert Menzies which is still admired by most of those who sit opposite.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, relates to the review being undertaken of the Government's assets test proposals and, in particular, to the effect it will have on the date that any subsequent test will come into effect. Because of the immense concern that has been expressed to me by the Combined Pensioners Association and other individual elderly citizens about what they should do with their current assets in case there is retrospective legislation, I ask: Firstly, can it be assumed, for the protection from worry of these people, that the restrospective operation provisions concerning deprivation of income and assets that was to apply from 24 August 1983 will not now take place? Secondly, will immediate action be taken by the Government to clarify its position in this matter with pensioners, so that they can make responsible decisions in dealing with their current assets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Social Security, I provide Senator Missen with the following information. In the Minister's statement on the assets test on Budget night last year he announced that from 24 August 1983 the disposal of assets without adequate consideration would constitute deprivation of assets for the purposes of the test. That provision was included in the test to ensure that in the period between the announcement of the test and its actual implementation people would not be able to circumvent it by disposing of assets that would otherwise be assessable. This, of course, is similar to common practice in relation to changes in the tax system that are aimed at addressing tax avoidance practices and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: Pending the outcome of the review of the assets test that is currently being undertaken, these provisions will continue to apply at least until the Government has made a decision on the panel's report. If they did not apply and if the Government does decide to introduce an assets test, such a test would be quite ineffective as it would provide opportunities for people to dispose of assets prior to the test's introduction. At the same time, I note that these provisions do not prevent pensioners selling or reducing their assets for legitimate reasons, such as the purchase of consumer goods, home maintenance or improvements or to finance--
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Missen at least is quite interested in the information that I am able to provide on behalf of the Minister for Social Security. So I repeat that the provisions do not prevent pensioners from selling or reducing their assets for legitimate reasons, such as for the purchase of consumer goods, home maintenance or home improvements or to finance trips or holidays. I also point out that by maintaining these provisions, as contained in the Bill that has been tabled in the House, nothing has changed in relation to pensioners' expectations concerning the test. Prior to the announcement of the review, pensioners were aware that any deprivation of assets they undertook between 24 August and the introduction of the test would be covered under the test. In this respect continuation of the provisions, at least until the Government has made a decision on the panel's report, changes nothing and has no additional impact on pensioners. I hope that information assists Senator Missen.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister not agree that the extended period while the Government makes up its mind means that many pensioners who are worried by this proposal have no possibility, perhaps, of making certain decisions, and that people of considerable age are therefore stuck in that position until the Government makes up its mind?

—I do not agree with this scaremongering in which Senator Missen, I might say quite uncharacteristically, is engaging. Senator Missen knows, and I am sure that pensioners throughout the country know, that the Government is currently undertaking the review. There is adequate participation of pensioners and groups representing pensioners in that review. I am sure that the attempts to whip up insecurity, that the Opposition seems to be intent upon, will fail totally.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ADVISORY AND CO-ORDINATING COMMITTEE ON MULTICULTURAL EDUCATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. Has the recently appointed National Advisory and Co-ordinating Committee on Multicultural Education held its first meeting? If so, can the Minister give some indication of priorities established by the Committee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Giles's question is timely. The first meeting of the National Multicultural Advisory Committee is taking place as I speak. I think that it is of interest to many honourable senators, and certainly to ethnic communities and to those in the community who have been supporting multiculturalism, that this Government has done what the previous Government was asked to do on many occasions but failed to do; that is, to set up a national body to advise the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs on the development of multicultural education. I was pleased to be able to take this initiative on behalf of the Government. I took it after very wide advertisement and promotion of the idea of the Committee.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to announce that the Committee has a very wide representation of competent persons from many different ethnic backgrounds, all of whom have expertise in the education area. The Committee is chaired by Professor Jayasuriya, who is head of the Department of Social Work and Social Administration at the University of Western Australia and is very well known in the area of multiculturalism. Other members of the Committee are equally able, I believe, to make a very important contribution.

As to the priorities that the Committee will adopt, as I explained to members of the Committee today, that is a matter for their consideration, but I drew their attention to a number of areas which our Government sees as priorities in the area. They include the development of a national language policy; the development of a policy towards the teaching of community languages in schools and perhaps what must precede that, the preparation of teachers for the teaching of community languages in schools; the development of the participation and equity program to accommodate the needs of young people in secondary education who are from a variety of ethnic backgrounds; and our objectives with regard to establishing equal opportunity for girls and women at all levels of education. There are a number of initiatives taking place in various States and Territories and, of course, there are initiatives outside the state system in independent schools, the Catholic school system and so on.

So, I am looking forward to having a very constructive relationship with this Committee. I am please to report to the Senate that the Committee has expressed, on behalf of the various organisations and community groups that it represents, its satisfaction with the Commonwealth initiative in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask the Minister to table the paper from which she has extensively quoted.

—I am quite happy to table the papers, but I must point out that I have no prepared answer. I have a number of papers, which contain a number of facts by which no doubt Senator Chaney will be much illumined.
—The Minister does not claim them to be confidential. I take it that you are prepared to table the papers, Senator?

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable senator to place his question on notice.

—I direct my question to the Attorney-General. What is the Government's response to the recent agreement between the Victorian Labor Government and its Liberal Party Opposition on parliamentary reform, hailed yesterday by Mr Cain and Mr Kennett as the most fundamental constitutional change in Victoria this century? Will the Minister explain why the Liberal Party members here, unlike their Victorian counterparts, cannot accept the democratic virtue of a four-year parliamentary term with a minimum fixed term of three years?

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. This question contains a gross misrepresentation of fact. The Opposition supported four-year terms, and the question is predicated on a totally false set of facts and should be withdrawn.
—There is no point of order at this stage.

—I continue with the question. Has the Government any reason to hope that the Opposition in this place will accept the reality of stable government, as its Opposition colleagues in Sydney and Melbourne have already done?
—Order! Insofar as the question relates to the administration of the Minister's portfolio, I would ask him to restrict his remarks to that aspect .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very closely related to matters of high public policy in this Parliament, Mr President. I think that it is appropriate that we should understand the implications of the recent Victorian development. I acknowledge the point made about the support of the other side of this chamber, perhaps only temporary, for four-year terms. That was not, of course, the nub of Senator Ray' s question. It was the concept of four-year terms with a minimum fixed term of three years. Those were the terms in which the question was asked, and those were the terms in which the concept has been accepted by the Victorian Liberals. The Victorian Liberals' acceptance of that proposition is a fascinating development and one that puts the position of the national Liberal Party absolutely to shame.

ANSWER.PARA: There are very real and obvious advantages in a system of fixed term parliaments, including the modified version of that system which has now been developed in Australia. There are advantages of fewer elections, of a more rational political climate generally, better opportunities for planning and a general situation of stability and continuity in government, which is a precondition of good government.

The present Government remains, as it always has been, of the belief that there are enormous advantages and merits associated with a fixed term parliament system. What we were forced to conclude last year, given the strident and noisome opposition of the kind that is being expressed here today, was that there is simply no prospect of rational debate in the Australian community on this matter so long as the Opposition parties approach it with the dog in the manger attitude which they have expressed so often in the past and are expressing here again today.

The utility of a fixed term system goes not only to continuity, stability and rationality in the election cycle. It also has great practical utility in resolving some of the deadlocks and dilemmas that flow from the relationship between two Houses of this kind. It is a measure, again, of the Opposition's unwillingness to accept the realities of the democratic process and the proper role of this chamber in it that the Opposition should maintain, as it has, its fierce opposition to any such system. Our position remains one that, recognising -

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. This is almost becoming a ministerial statement. Why cannot the Minister deliver it out of Question Time , thus giving some of us a better chance of asking a question? Things have been going on like this for weeks.
—There is no point of order. I ask the Minister to restrict his remarks to the question.

—The reality is that there is no point whatsoever in pursuing the notion of fixed terms in any form whatsoever so long as there is an absence of any degree of bipartisan support for it. That has been the history of referendums in this country, and that was the realisation that forced this Government to the position that it has now had to adopt, of putting the concept of fixed terms in cold storage. We simply ask that the Liberals and their National Party accompanists over there appreciate the historical significance of the step that has been taken in Victoria and learn from that example.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. It concerns the cutting off from unemployment benefit of a number of part time students at the Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education. Is the Minister aware that the local office of the Department of Social Security has no firm guidelines to advise it as to the amount of study which renders a part time student ineligible for unemployment benefit? When does a student, by virtue of study load, become ineligible for unemployment benefit? In that event, how does she expect those students to eat or to live? In view of the lack of guidelines, how are the officers of the Department of Social Security supposed to know how to judge individual students as being eligible or ineligible for this support?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say it is amazing that Senator Baume, having not all that long ago presided over the education portfolio and the very inadequate provision of tertiary allowances to students, should decide to take on the cause of students who are too poor to even support themselves. As Senator Baume of all people in this place will be very well aware, we inherited a situation in which the level of the tertiary education assistance scheme had declined considerably in terms of its purchasing value over a period of years, a seven-year period in which increases in TEAS had been few and far between and extremely minor. Therefore I must say I am surprised that he suddenly finds sympathy with the cause of students who do not have enough income to support themselves properly.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the publicity that has been given to the situation in Lismore. The administration of the unemployment benefit is, of course, the responsibility of the Department of Social Security. The Department of Social Security, in the absence of the Minister, has provided the following information although I must say before I give it that I find it extremely surprising that any Social Security office operating and paying out benefits would not have available to it the information about eligibility concerning the number of hours a student can study before he or she becomes ineligible. The information that has been provided to me does not take up that point. I will ask the Department of Social Security to provide for Senator Baume's benefit information about what guidelines are available to the office in Lismore. However, I would be extremely surprised if this matter were not known to those officers since there has been no change for a number of years. Unfortunately there has been no change; I would like to think that there could be changes in the forthcoming Budget. Senator Baume would, of course, know this since they were guidelines that would have affected his administration of TEAS in the education portfolio. The information provided by the Department is as follows:

To qualify for an unemployment benefit a person must satisfy a delegate of the Director-General of Social Security that in each benefit period he or she is unemployed, capable of and willing to undertake suitable paid work and taking reasonable steps to obtain such work.

Generally a person engaged in full-time studies would not be able to meet these requirements. Student claimants are interviewed to ascertain all the relevant facts of the case and particularly their intention to enter the workforce.
Where benefit is granted and there is some doubt as to a student's continuing eligibility, further interviews are carried out at appropriate intervals.

Revised instructions have been issued by the department to ensure that unemployment benefit is paid to claimants who are unemployed and have a genuine intention to find and accept suitable full-time work at the first opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My question to the Minister specifically concerned students enrolled part time all of whom claim that they are available for full time work. I ask the Minister: What is the boundary point at which part time students are deemed under the guidelines not to be available to undertake full time work? That is the point at which they lose their benefit.

—If Senator Baume had paid attention to the information that was provided, obviously the matter is one for determination on the merits of an individual case. If students are interviewed and then re-interviewed as to their eligibility obviously their willingness and availability for full time work is something they have an opportunity to establish. I do not want to defend the application of these guidelines in every case. Obviously I am in no position to do that. As I have said I have no information about particular guidelines available in the offices in Lismore but quite clearly the judgment is one of whether the students are ready and available to undertake full time work. If they are then, according to the guidelines set out here, they ought to be entitled to unemployment benefit. However, I will have to seek further information from the Department about the specific judgments that are being made in the Lismore case. In conclusion I simply repeat that this sudden interest in students with low incomes is quite remarkable coming from the former Minister for Education in a government which was tougher on students than any other government in the history of this country.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the situation of women in China, I think it is not always very helpful to try to make direct comparisons between, in our case, a democracy with a population of over 14 million people and, in the case of China, a system which is not a democratic system and which has a population in excess of 900 million. I conclude by saying that in the view of our Government-it is a view backed up by a vast range of statistical information and a view I think shared by many Opposition senators-there are many basic unmet needs by women in Australian society and we consider it the business of our Government to develop policies to meet those needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General and follows his lengthy lecture on the question of a four-year parliament. I ask the Attorney- General with respect to that proposition which he will recall had the support of the Opposition as well as the Government: Has the Government had access to market research on the acceptability of that particular proposal for a four-year term in the different States of Australia? Certainly that is something that the Government has taken into account in its current consideration of the proposals that will be put forward to referendum later in the year. —I ask a supplementary question. The Attorney-General referred to research which was commissioned by, I think he used the expression, 'us'. I ask: Who paid for the research that was commissioned by 'us'? Was it the Labor Party or the taxpayer through the administration of this Government?
—I am not sure that I can give an answer to that question. I believe it was government funded research as is perfectly proper and appropriate when one is talking about--
—Well, table it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

I incorporate the detailed answer in Hansard for the benefit of Senator Sibraa and other honourable senators.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The statements made by the officers of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES ) and the Department of Social Security are not considered at variance. A person is required to register for work with the CES in order to be eligible for unemployment benefit. However, the Department of Social Security has the responsibility to decide eligibility to unemployment benefit.

The determination of eligibility for unemployment benefit of persons unemployed as a result of industrial action requires careful gathering of all the factors precipitating the dispute and considering these facts against the criteria set out in the legislation. A person can not be deterred from lodging a claim for benefit at any time during the course of a dispute.
A married woman may claim unemployment benefit at any time and her entitlement is decided in accordance with the provisions of the Social Security Act.

In relation to unemployment benefit the Social Security Act provides that payment may be made from and including the seventh day after the day on which a person became unemployed or after the day on which he/she made a claim for unemployment benefit, whichever is the later.
Generally speaking, the date of registration with the CES is accepted as the date on which a person makes a claim for unemployment benefit.

Where a person can show that he/she was unemployed, capable of undertaking and willing to undertake suitable work and taking reasonable steps to obtain such work prior to claiming, the date of commencement of benefit can be advanced by the appropriate period up to seven days.

Any persons who feel they have met these conditions prior to the lodgement of a claim may have the matter reviewed at the local office of the Department. Of course any person who is not satisfied with a decision of the Department has a right of appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and ultimately to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
Neither the Minister for Social Security nor the Department of Social Security has any discretion to dackdate unemployment benefit claims by miners' wives to the date of their husbands' claims.

Where a person is experiencing hardship whilst awaiting payment of unemployment benefit, or where a wife is unable to qualify for unemployment benefit, special benefit may be payable. I am advised that these cases of special benefit may commence from the date of the husband's claim for benefit.

The statement of 29 March 1984 in the Broken Hill newspaper was made by the Commonwealth Employment Service not by the Department of Social Security. This response has been cleared with the office of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.
