DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's rush to an unnecessary election this year before economic recovery fades and its deferral of unpopular issues until after that election.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: -The Opposition is bringing forward this matter of public importance for reasons which, in part, are demonstrated by the display we had in Question Time today when, under the guise of answering questions, Government Ministers used the opportunity to obscure the situation rather than provide facts for the Australian people to make judgments. I suppose that the attempts of the Attorney -General (Senator Gareth Evans) to obscure the position on the four-year term for Parliament was the classic but not unusual example in what has been a most unsatisfactory Question Time. On that occasion the Attorney-General was trying to suggest that, in some way, the Opposition had subverted the idea of the four- year term when, of course, it is quite evident-that evidence comes in part from the Attorney's own answer in Question Time-that the Government's own election manoeuvering has resulted in its changing its own proposals for referendum. That is so typical of everything that this Government is presently doing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's matter of public importance is based on two easily sustainable assertions. We say the Prime Minister wants an early election because he is worried about the future of the economy. We say that because he is going to have this election he has decided to avoid any potentially unpopular issues until after the poll. During the election campaign in February last year Mr Hawke said : 'Under my government parliaments will run their full time'. In February 1983 Mr Hawke said that parliaments under him would run their full time. Now in 1984 Mr Hawke has made it clear that he will have an early election either late this year or perhaps early next year, but almost certainly later this year. That is just one broken promise among many.

We know that when the Prime Minister gained government in 1983 he recanted on virtually every undertaking given before the election. He always has an excuse. In this case there are two possible excuses that he will use for an early election. The first is that he wants to synchronise the House of Representatives election with the Senate election. Or he might choose to use the excuse he floated in Adelaide just a few weeks ago relating to Senate obstruction. Very briefly in anticipation I will dispose of those two arguments of Mr Hawke. Does he have a case for an election this year to synchronise the House of Representatives election with the Senate election? My response is to say that such an election is totally unnecessary. In fact, a much later election could be held bringing the election of both Houses together. What the Australian people are facing is the prospect of the shortest parliament for many a parliament. They are facing a term of office of somewhere around a year and a half for Mr Hawke's Government when in fact Mr Hawke could run through until at least May next year and still have a House of Representatives election-albeit an early one -in conjunction with the Senate election. Somehow the idea has been put abroad that in order to bring the election of the two Houses together Mr Hawke needs to have this election this year. That is not true. It is inaccurate. It is a lie. It is a lie which should be put to rest.
We have heard Mr Hawke talk about Senate obstruction. According to a radio broadcast, he got a very good reception to a speech he made on 18 or 19 April in Adelaide. He is reported as saying:
Our major attack on tax avoidance has been frustrated by what has happened in the Senate.
Mr Hawke in that speech then said to the Liberals, the Nationals and the Australian Democrats:
I give . . . notice, that they will be hounded and reminded of that fact for every week between now and the election.

That is good political stuff. It is absolutely farcical when we note that a senior Minister who was very active in the arguments about tax avoidance in Australia and who, somewhat to his surprise, was caught up personally in such arguments, within a matter of days of Mr Hawke's fulminating about the Senate role in protecting tax avoiders, said that tax avoidance was no longer an issue in Australia. Mr Dawkins on 16 April told a conference of accountants in Sydney that tax avoidance was no longer an issue in Australia and that the Government had 'put the question of tax avoidance behind them'. That is a ludicrous statement if we are to take Mr Hawke's statement seriously. the fact of the matter is that it is Mr Hawke who made the ludicrous statement. He is not to be taken seriously. He is running this as a political rort because it is known throughout Australia that the tax avoidance industry was destroyed by the Fraser Government. This Government now is merely trying to resurrect the issue to damage the Senate.

We have brought on this debate because we are concerned that there should be some factual information available to the Australian people instead of the lies being peddled by members of the Government. We believe that it is absolutely important that we should see what the Government is up to and why it is rushing to this early election. In this regard I will first deal with the economic outlook. I will not rely on Opposition assessments of where the economy is going because it might be argued that the Opposition is a doom sayer, is trying to talk the economy down and is trying to damn the Government for partisan political advantage. In fact, the Opposition welcomes the current signs of economic improvement. At the same time we point out, as indeed does almost every economic commentator, that the improvement has occurred almost in spite of the Hawke Government's policies and statements and arises largely from the Fraser Government's wage pause, the pick-up in the United States economy and the much brighter rural outlook following the breaking of the drought. Commentator after commentator has made the point that these factors are the foundation of the economic upsurge over the last year. We would all hope to see that fledgling recovery permanently sustained. However, we are all being advised by almost every economic commentator that there are enormous risks ahead.

As far as the Opposition can ascertain, there are no reputable economic commentators prepared to predict that 1985 will see a continuation of the current upturn. If Government senators come in here and say 'We believe there will be an economic upturn and you are engaging in scare mongering' I issue a challenge. If they believe that let them ask their Prime Minister to postpone the election so that we and the people of Australia can wait and see what happens. I guarantee that we will not get that challenge taken up. We will not see the Labor Party holding off an election in order to see whether its policies are working but one which will go helter-skelter to an election at the earliest possible opportunity.

As I said earlier, it is not the Opposition's view that I am promoting that there will be difficulties for the next year and the years beyond; it is the view of commentator after commentator. The most recent independent public statement was the reported submission by the Australian Merchant Bankers Association. The Association made a submission to the Government's own economic advisory body, the Economic Planning and Advisory Council. The Merchant Bankers Association predicted a shrinking of the economy in the financial year 1985-86. It predicted a short term drop in inflation and a rise the year after. On the critical question of unemployment the Association is saying:
Unemployment will bottom out at 8.8 per cent in 1984-85, but will rise to 10.5 per cent in 1985-86 and 11.5 per cent in 1986-87.

What we face is a prediction which confirms the predictions which the Government 's own bodies put down at the Economic Summit last year, namely, that if we return to full wage indexation there will be a gradual rise in unemployment. We have had the benefit of seasonal and one-off charges to the economy which have affected some improvement. However, the long term prospect is much gloomier. At nearly the same time the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures in its monthly summary said that its predictions paint a fairly dismal picture of the Australian economy. The fact is that most people believe that the rest of this year will see the maintenance of economic growth but most have reservations about 1985 because of the potential for wage rises and the generally unsatisfactory nature of the long term recovery. Mr Des Keegan of the Australian in a report yesterday said:
Cheerful forecasts of economic recovery should fade as disturbing export figures seep into public opinon in 1984-85. Reality is overtaking propaganda.

He also made the point, which is in line with the view which we in the Opposition have been urging now for some months, namely that private advice to the Government urges it to go to the polls before the economy strands it on the dangerous economic shoals which are ahead. In another enconomic commentary, much objected to by the Government which seems to object to anybody having a view which is contrary to the view of the Government itself holds, Mr P. P. McGuiness , the editor of the Australian Financial Review, said on 10 April:

The current economic recovery will be short-lived. It is the inheritance of the Labor Government from the Fraser Government and the breaking of the drought, and the inheritance will be soon dissipated.
Only today the same newspaper said in its leading article:
The balance of probabilities is that the effect of wage indexation, even with an artificially low CPI, will tend to abort the economic recovery within the remainder of 1984.

Again, within the last month or so Hill Samuel Ltd, a merchant bank, has drawn attention to the fragile nature of the recovery. I stress that I do not raise those matters from the point of view of wishing those things to happen. I do not raise them as being the forecast of the Opposition. Rather, I raise them as examples of what is being said very broadly among the well-informed in the community about the nature of economic recovery which has been achieved by this Government. It has been achieved because of its inheritance. It is an achievement which it is dissipating by failing to come to grips with the real issues which dog the Australian economy.

In the currently relatively cheery atmosphere in Australia, in the circumstances in which informed opinion is making it clear to the Government that it faces real problems next year, we can understand the urgency of feeling within the Australian Labor Party, the urgency of feeling within the Government, the urgency of feeling within the breast of Mr R. J. Hawke that he must take himself back to the Australian people before they wake up to what the experts are unanimously pointing to. So we are facing a situation in which the Government is getting near uniform advice that it will be in real difficulties in the future. It is not prepared-indeed, I think it would say that it is totally unable-to come to grips with the policies that are required to do something about next year and the year beyond that. Therefore, it must pick up the option of an early election.

Again, it is no secret among informed people, but I am sure it is still dimly perceived by the electorate generally, that the Government as part of its early election strategy set out to remove those irritants which might cause the public to question its policies. Of course, the Senate has tended to be the forum in which those potentially difficult policy issues have been raised and where the Government has seen itself getting into difficulties. The fact of the matter is that the Government has shown itself quite unprepared to come to grips with any issue on which there is a serious clash between it and the Opposition and the possibility of a serious clash with public opinion.

Let us look at just a few of the issues which are around: The assets test, a capial gains tax, a Bill of rights, lump sum superannuation, national Aboriginal land legislation and the education issue. We do not see a resolute government pushing on with the policies that new senators such as the honourable senator sitting opposite, Senator Crowley, were elected on the basis of and went around telling their constituents they supported. Those policies are being pushed aside because of this early election strategy. There is a very simple explanation for that. A recent survey was taken on the assets test and a capital gains tax. We found that 57 per cent of the Australian people disagreed with the proposal that the Government has for an assets test for pensioners. We found that 70 per cent of the Australian people disagreed with the proposition which is supported by Senator Button and many other Government honourable senators and many other Ministers, that we should move to a capital gains tax. So it is not surprising that the Government has chosen to take those matters off the political agenda.

Let us look at what happened in respect of the assets test. Legislation for it was introduced by the Government at the time of the last Budget. It was made clear to us that the Government was determined that it would legislate for that assets test. The Government roundly criticised us for political opportunism when we raised the question of the concern in the community about the test and suggested there should be a delay. It was only when the Opposition, in conjunction with the Australian Democrats, determined it would delay the assets test until February to enable pensioners and others to put views to the Government that the Government did not proceed with that legislation. We found that by February this year, the Opposition having been abused for its daring to delay this Government measure, the Prime Minister had completely changed his tune. Rather to the surprise we believe of the responsible Minister, the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, we found that Mr Hawke admitted the test was defective; he admitted that it had not been thought through properly and sent it off to an expert committee. I ask the Government: Will it produce a fresh assets test before the next election? Will it disclose its intentions to the Australian people? I for one have very serious doubts that it will.

With respect to a capital gains tax, I suppose the Government has been almost disarmingly frank: That is a matter for the next Parliament. Seventy per cent of the Australian people disagree, so that is a matter for the next Parliament. The Government will not make up its mind. The Government will not tell the Australian people what it proposes. It puts that on to the back burner. It hides it away. It tries to make it into a non-issue.

On a Bill of rights, we all have sat in this Senate and been lectured by the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, about his law reform proposals. We have been lectured about our slowness in government and his determination to set new records in law reform. He came into this Parliament a few weeks ago and said: ' We can't proceed with the Bill of rights because it will be a pre-election atmosphere. Everybody is emotional in a pre-election atmosphere, so that is something we will have to put off. Of course, it is still Government policy but it is something we have to put off'. That is again part of the same strategy.

Let us look at lump sum superannuation. As long ago as May last year this Government announced it would introduce a new form of taxation of lump sum superannuation. It was part of this Government's first brave steps to change Australia. That was May last year and still we have not seen the legislation. Again I ask the Government: Will we see that legislation before the election? Will the Government show the Australian people what it is up to, or is that another one which is on the agenda for the next time around?

I come to the vexed question, the very difficult question, of national Aboriginal land legislation. It is a matter of common knowledge that this Government has been told by its State counterparts in my State of Western Australia to lay off and go away. I say to those senators who went out and so bravely promised the Aboriginal people of Australia national land rights legislation: I will bet anything you like that you will not deliver on that promise because you know the politics of it. They know that it is something which would not receive popular support around Australia. They will not go ahead with that promise. It is off the agenda between now and the next election.

The fact of the matter is that Mr Hawke is the most popular and least courageous Prime Minister this country has ever had. Mr Hawke has shown no preparedness really to disclose where he stands on these issues. He has shown his preparedness only to sun himself under his popularity lamp. That is the sort of man he is. He is the man who suns himself under the popularity lamp. He is a man who does not have the courage of his convictions. I only wish to say that we achieved the great privilege of having some new Labor senators in this place. I ask them to go back to the ideas they expressed when they campaigned to become members of this place. I ask them to go back to what they promised the Australian people. I ask them to come into this place and honestly say whether they delivered what they promised. Of course it is an absurd question to put to them because there is no way that they would show that degree of honesty.

We in the Opposition believe that Australia has significant and real problems. We believe that the vexed problem of unemployment which has beset us now for some time is not going to go away. We do not believe that the fundamental policies of this Government, which involve a cosy arrangement between those who have to the exclusion of those who have not, are in the long term interests of this country. We do not accept the fundamentals which this Government is embracing and believe that this Government is maintaining itself only by a thoroughly dishonest approach to government. We believe that, unless the Australian people see that, there is no prospect that this popular but cowardly Prime Minister will face up to the real issues which face Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the terms of this matter of public importance first arrived today it raised a lot of speculation in the Australian Labor Party on just how pathetic the Opposition was going to be. The matter of public importance is about the Government rushing into an unnecessary election this year. I point out that as yet there has been no decision to have an election this year. That is an assumption on the part of the Opposition. It is an assumption born of fear.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a need for a joint election, we believe, before mid-1985. I think the reasons are fairly clear and are understood even by those opposite. The first is to bring the two Houses back into kilter so that we can have simultaneous elections. There is a strong argument on an economy basis to have joint elections rather than separate elections and that is the cost to the taxpayer. Finally, there is the political reason, a reason which neither a Liberal government nor a Labor government would any longer deny: That a half-Senate election held by itself is just a benefit for minority parties. We will never see a Liberal Party of Australia government go for a half-Senate election by itself ever again. We will never see an Australian Labor Party government doing it. When last it was done, in 1970, the Liberal Government responsible lived to regret it for many years. It meant that independent or small party candidates won in every State but South Australia and there they missed out by only about one-half of one per cent.

The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) has the gall to criticise an anticipated decision of the Labor Party to bring about an early election. Senator Chaney's Party has brought about seven early elections in the last 33 years. Every early election in Australia can be traced back to the conservatives in this country. Let us have a look at the record. Let us go through the early elections and see who is at fault. The last early election was in 1983. (Quorum formed) The Leader of the Opposition referred to the Prime Minister as cowardly. Yet the Opposition is not willing to cop any stick in return. That is typical of it. Before I was interrupted I was saying that those opposite have provoked seven early elections in the last 33 years, yet have the gall to criticise us in anticipation that we may once, since Federation, pull on an early election. Let us look at the circumstances of the last seven occasions. In 1983 the man whom Senator Chaney used to worship, Mr Fraser, called on an early election. Why did he call an early election? Was it because he was trying to hide an economy going bad or something? He called on an early election for political opportunism. He thought that the Labor Party was going to blow itself apart. He thought that he could cash in on a leadership crisis, so he called an election. On election night he broke down and cried when he lost. That is case No. 1.

I go to case No. 2. In 1977 Senator Chaney's hero, Mr Fraser, again called an election one year early. Why did he call it? The reason he gave to the public was that he wanted to bring the Houses back into synchronisation to have elections together, the very anticipated reason that Mr Hawke may call an election later this year or next year. But what Mr Fraser was particularly trying to do was again to cash in on what he saw as internal Labor Party problems and the perception that Mr Whitlam could not win an election and might be replaced. Let us go back to the previous two early elections. Who caused the early election in 1975? Those opposite and their colleagues caused it. They had the Government tipped out because they thought correctly that they would win an election. Let us look at the previous example-1974. Who caused that early election? It was Mr Snedden and his cronies. Let us go back to 1963. There was an early election then brought on by Menzies. That was the very thing that put the two Houses out of kilter and allowed for separate Senate elections. So Mr Menzies, the other great hero of the Liberal Party, called early elections. He did so again in 1955. Can Senator Chaney or anyone on that side tell me why there was an early election in 1955? It was to cash in on internal Labor Party problems. Why was there an early election in 1951? It was so that the Liberal Party could run a bodgie double dissolution to try to get control of this Parliament.

Every example of an early election since Federation has been perpetrated by the conservatives, the Liberals. Yet here today they criticise us. Are we not allowed one out of ten? Are we not allowed one early election this century? Of course we are not, because those opposite want to play with two different sets of rules, both written by them. Why do those opposite fear an early election? Why does the Liberal Party not want an election? I will tell them very simply. It is because the economy is recovering, we have inflation to its lowest level in five or six years, unemployment is dropping, and hundreds of thousands of jobs have been created. Those opposite are not willing to face the people. They were willing in 1974 and 1975 to say that it was good for a Labor government to face the people. They assisted us twice to face the people. But now, when they might get done, they squib it; they are not interested in having an election because they know what will happen-we will cream them. Those opposite can quote this back to me next year after the election if I am wrong-we will absolutely cream them in the election.

There is a second reason why those opposite do not want an early election: We have the most popular Prime Minister in the history of the country. What have they got? They have Mr Peacock, put in by the two speakers on the Liberal side, Senator Withers and Senator Chaney. He is their friend; he is their leader; and he is absolutely pathetic. It is very hard in politics to achieve perfection, but Mr Peacock is a perfect mediocre individual. He has done absolutely nothing in leading the Opposition in the other place. Even his own members wince every time he gets up. So the second reason those opposite do not want an early election is that they have a pathetic leader, and they know it. Mr Fraser recognised that when he tried to have Senator Chaney transferred into the House of Representatives as a potential leader. Even though at times I am critical of Senator Chaney, I acknowledge that he would be better than Peacock.

A third reason why those opposite do not want an early election is that they have no policies. They have had three policy launches. What have we got from them? We got absolutely nothing. There were 12 pages of rhetoric in their economic policy. They are going to flog off a couple of government enterprises, and that is that. It must have taken them a long time to work that out! They have launched a wages policy, trying to take us back to the stone age by doing away with centralised wage fixing. Finally, they have adopted a foreign affairs policy. What they are in fact doing is going on the long march to the right. They are trying to take the Liberal Party to the right and they know that they will not win an election via that.

Senator Chaney today expressed the view that we are dodging hard issues. If any Party has dodged hard issues, it is Senator Chaney's Party and others. When have they ever tried to tackle the problem of the means test? They would not even consider it. No matter what the views are of how a government should work, it is much too hard for them to touch. When have they ever tackled the problem of a total reform of the taxation scales in this country? They were not willing to touch it. When were they ever willing to tackle the Conciliation and Arbitration Act as we have set up an inquiry to do? They are just not game. Yet they accuse the Prime Minister of political cowardice.

I believe that if those opposite were sincere in their worry about early elections they would have supported fixed term parliaments, but they have always sought continuously to sabotage anything that would take away from a Liberal Party leader the desire to go as early as possible. Senator Withers has been continually interjecting. He as much as anyone else was responsible for early elections on at least three different occasions in Australia-in 1974, 1975 and 1977.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a good judge!

—He is reputed to be a good political judge. I am not here to doubt that. But there is no doubt that he has worked out what is going to happen later this year. I am surprised that Senator Withers and others do not just concede that it will happen the following year anyway. If we do have an early election we will be putting them out of their pain just a little earlier. It is another example of the humanity of the Labor Government that we would seek to put those opposite out of their misery far earlier than otherwise. It is a phoney issue when those opposite say here that they object to our calling an early election. As I have pointed out, at least seven times in the last 33 years the Opposition has taken this country to an early election. It has done so for one reason and one reason only: It thought that by doing so it would politically advantage itself. When in opposition we gave the present Opposition the opportunity to take away the right of governments to call elections, by our proposal for fixed term parliaments. It rejected that. Now what it would like to do is to deny us our one opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not saying what our motives may or may not be for holding an early election. If the motive is political addvantage, it is no worse than anything that has ever been done in the past. Historically, I would regard it as a bit of justice. If the proposal for fixed terms of parliament had been adopted, what Senator Chaney calls the tough issues could be tackled far more effectively because governments would know exactly how long they had to run in office. That is why the proposals for four-year terms of government and such have a lot of appeal to me.

It is about time the Liberal Party tried to confront the issues. It is no use just hoping that the economy will turn bad. I am sure that is not the Opposition 's motive. It has to get out there, develop some policies, tackle the hard issues and put them to the Australian people. Next time it produces an economic policy it should be detailed. It should not be just a sort of philosophical thrill kill, something put out to excite its own supporters but nothing more than that. It should work on some detailed plans. The same goes for the wages area. I know it is very difficult for any Liberal party to develop a wages policy. It has the hardest job in the world, given its philosophy. But if it worked at some detail in those areas it would not have to tremble and worry about when the next election is to be. I would not like to be running No. 3 on any Liberal ticket, with seven senators being elected to the Senate. I can understand the Opposition's concern. We have great sympathy for it in that regard. But all it has shown today is how scared it is of an election, whenever it may be. As I said, that reflects a deficit of policy on behalf of the Opposition. It reflects poor leadership and the fact that the economy is recovering. As I said before-and the Opposition can throw it back in my face after the next election if I am wrong-we will cream the Opposition at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a matter of public importance which was brought on by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) , namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's rush to an unnecessary election this year before economic recovery fades and its deferral of unpopular issues until after that election.

Senator Robert Ray talked about all the previous early elections there have been in the past 20 or 30 years. We are not denying that one bit. There would hardly be a political leader who does not worship at the altar of political expediency. That has been done before. But in this instance we are dealing with a Prime Minister who said, prior to the last election: 'Under my Government parliaments will run their full time'. The Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, has already alluded to that. Straight after the election, on 6 March, the Canberra Times quoted the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, as replying to a question asked at a Press conference in the following terms:
I hope to try and rid Australia of this frequency of elections which above all else have been destabilising for our community.

As I said, previous Prime Ministers have had early elections. Many have worshipped at the altar of political expediency, but none have come out beforehand, as this Prime Minister has done, and said: 'We will have no part of early elections'. Yet the Prime Minister, having said that, is already taking us down that track. He is making no denial of it. An article which appeared on 16 December in the Adelaide Advertiser stated:
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said on Adelaide radio yesterday there could be an early election over the constitutional referendum issue.
Mr Hawke's stand came as the Senate voted to reject Government plans to fund only the 'Yes' case for the five constitutional changes proposed in the referendum planned for February 23.

For those people who do not quite understand, I explain that the Government planned to hold a referendum but intended to fund only its side of the story; the other case was not to get any funding at all. But because this Senate said no to that proposal the Prime Minister started talking about an early election because of the great constitutional crisis which was apparently upon us. That was on 16 December. As late as 13 January the Prime Minister was still on that track. An article which appeared in the Australian on that date reported:

Attacking the Senate for 'frustrating' the Government's referendum plans, Mr Hawke said it would be 'unusual' if an election were not held to coincide with the half-Senate poll due late this year or early next year.

The bandwagon was already rolling then. But then we had a change of tactics. We found another reason to have an early election. The reason then became the so- called frustration of the Government's tax plans. On 28 January-that is 15 days after we had been talking about the constitutional problem-the Sydney Morning Herald stated:

The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, yesterday laid the grounds for a possible double dissolution election later this year, by putting the Opposition on notice that he plans again to introduce bottom-of-the-harbour tax legislation.

Of course, as Senator Chaney said in his contribution to this debate, it was the Fraser Government which put an end to all the tax dodging schemes in this country. After Mr Hawke came to power new tax measures were to be introduced and made retrospective. In other words, people were to be called on to pay tax under a system which never existed prior to the Hawke Government coming to office. A new tax was to be introduced. People were to be asked to pay that tax in a retrospective manner, something which some of the Australian Democrats and the Liberal and National Party Opposition would not abide, and indeed still will not abide. But that was the new excuse for the election bandwagon to get rolling, from a Prime Minister who said: 'Under my Government parliaments will run their full term'.

What we basically have is a conning of the Australian electorate into a false sense of complacency when, in reality, it should be very concerned about where this Government is taking it. The fact is that the necessity for an early election, an election prior to about 5 May next year, is a fraud being perpetrated on the people, just as before the last election the fraud was perpetrated about all the things that were to happen, the wage reductions, the cheaper fuel and so the list goes on ad infinitum, ad nauseam. Those election promises have since proved to be a fraud. One of the big matters surrounding the last election concerned the projected deficit, which of course in the Government 's own words proved to be a fraud. Honourable senators will all recall the $9.6 billion projected deficit, in which most of the people of Australia believe. The media picked it up and ran with it. As I said to the people around the countryside, how can we have a projected deficit when we do not even have a Budget? Yet most people believed it. So this year we required the Government to give us the projected deficit figures for 1984-85. What happened? Speaking to the Age, Mr Hawke said: 'We cannot give you those figures because they would be illusory'. Answering a question in the other place, Mr Keating indicated that we would not be getting those sorts of figures because basically they are pretty meaningless. I understand that Mr Dawkins, that great man who does not like tax dodging but has been proved to have quite an Achilles' heel, said at the National Press Club luncheon: 'No, we are not giving those figures because they would be irrelevant'. What a fraud! What a fraud the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) is proving to be. What a fraud the Government has perpetrated on the people of this country. Any factors which have led to the improvement of the economy have travelled on the coat tails of the Fraser Government. As Senator Chaney and I have said, there is no need for any election whatsoever before May 1985. We all recognise that there has to be a half-Senate election then so that the new Senate can take its place and the writs can be returned by 1 July.

Senator Robert Ray dwelt on the economy picking up and being buoyant, which is not true. Nobody would believe that. The economy might be returning to where it should have been before the disastrous drought that overtook Australia. Of course, if ever there has been a lesson for city dwellers on the impact of the rural sector of this nation upon the economy, it has been that drought. The breaking of that drought and the fact that the economy has started to come back to some normalcy should be an indication to the people who live in the cities that rural Australia still plays a tremendous part in the Australian economy. If we take away the breaking of the drought, where is the recovery? This Government has done nothing. Of course, it is working on a very basic principle that if it does not do anything, it will not hurt anybody. We have seen that principle in operation in the Parliament because very little legislation is being introduced. The Government has done nothing, so it has not hurt anybody. It is travelling on the coat tails of the Fraser Government's initiatives. It has done only two things in regard to the financial system. It will deregulate it and will probably allow the entry of foreign banks into Australia. Those initiatives are not ALP policy. They are basically the coalition parties' policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Medicare?

—What about Medicare? I did not think any member of the Government would be game to mention Medicare. What a disaster has been thrust upon this country! It is said that nine out of 10 people will have cheaper medical costs. What utter rot! Even the Government does not believe that the one per cent levy will cover the astronomical cost that Medicare will put on the Australian people, let alone the inconvenience, the socialisation or nationalisation of medicine which is taking place today, or the fact that all medical researchers, doctors and specialists, if the Government gets its way, will ultimately be beholden to a federal government. The medical system in Australia will stagnate and will be driven to a standstill by this nationalisation, as has happened in every country-indeed, in every country that we have supposedly followed-that has tried this scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Chaney said, we have a Prime Minister who, while basking in the sunlamp of popularity, is not game to bite any of the economic bullets which need to be bitten in order to get this country on the road again. The deficit is blowing out and the Government will not be game to reduce it. It will not be game to assist the private sector. It is not really game to tackle the wages problem when, as every economist will say, and as I indicated, it is riding on the coat tails of the Fraser economic initiatives. Leaving aside the breaking of the drought and the upturn in the American economy, it is still reaping the benefits to be derived from the wages pause initiative. Since this Government came to office there have been wage rises of 8.4 per cent across the board in six months, something which no other country against which we are competing in world markets has had to endure. That indicates that we are heading down the track towards all sorts of problems.

Let us talk about the consumer price index. Of course, all the commentators are pointing out-the Labor Government apparently does not want to recognise it-how artificial the CPI is. If a person takes out private health insurance, it is taken as part of the CPI calculations. But if the Government rips it off a person, it is not used as part of the CPI calculation. So we have an artificial lowering of the CPI which, of course, affects pensioners most of all. All of those who are on indexed pensions or who are recipients of any benefits from the Commonwealth Government will be hurt, because they are enduring the costs but are not receiving the benefits because of this artificial reduction in the CPI.

One other reason that we can garner that the Government is heading towards an early election is the intimidation of the media, particularly of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. After the last election, during questioning and debates in this chamber, we dragged out of the Government the fact that the Prime Minister, when he was Leader of the Opposition prior to the election, got on the phone and threatened Dame Leonie Kramer so that he would get his way. That occurred because of a program that was broadcast on the ABC. Of course, all the allegations that were made in that program have been borne out in the courts in New South Wales. But it was despicable for a Leader of the Opposition who hoped to become Prime Minister to get on the phone and threaten the head of the ABC, Dame Leonie Kramer. We know, through the channels of the Senate, that that happened. Ultimately, the ABC went its way and Dame Leonie Kramer was not appointed to the Corporation. We now have a Hawke appointed Board, and he is threatening to cut its funding. There has been complete intimidation of the ABC. In today's Age, an article by Laurie Oakes states:
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the managing director of the ABC, Mr Geoffrey Whitehead, have discussed proposals for special procedures to allow politicians to make complaints to the corporation.

A controversial proposal considered at a meeting between the two men last Friday involved the establishment of a direct line of communication between the Prime Minister's Press office and senior ABC management.
Have honourable senators ever in their lives heard of such despicable intimidation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful.

—It is shameful that the Prime Minister is considering a situation whereby he could phone senior management of the ABC from his office and intimidate them with regard to things that he did not like. If we put together all of these facts, one can only agree that this Government is taking us down the track to an early election because it is not game to bite the bullets that need to be bitten in the Australian economy. The fact that we will have an early election is in itself destabilising, as the Prime Minister has said. Already the business community does not know where it is heading. He has already blamed the business community because the upturn in the economy has not occurred. So we can see that he is painting the scenario, as he takes us down this inevitable track. But reality is overtaking the Government's propaganda line. Fortuitously, the people of Australia are slowly waking up to what is going on. Fortuitously, the business community and the farming community are doing the same.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

(Quorum formed) I had not even finished explaining to the Senate the farcical nature of this matter of public importance before the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) felt that I should have a larger audience. I think it is fair to say that there are four-actually five, at a further count-Opposition senators present. Clearly, the Opposition does not feel it is necessary to listen to its speakers in this most significant discussion about unnecessary elections before economic recovery fades, or the deferral of unpopular issues until after the election. It seems to choke in the Opposition's throat that the Labor Government can play politics too.

SPEECH.PARA: It needs to be understood first, if we start with facts and resort to rhetoric later, that the principal reason that there has to be an election late this year or early next year is the decision taken by the then Prime Minister, Mr Malcom Fraser, to call a double dissolution for March last year. It is due to that, and to nothing else, that we have to have a Senate election before May 1985.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then the big jib cried.

—I think it could be said, Senator Ray, that the best way that it was all described was by Tandberg in that endlessly repeated cartoon of endlessly exact humour. Mr Fraser has required the necessity for a half Senate election late this year or early next year, and Mr Hawke, being well aware of the cost to the taxpayer of unnecessary elections, has hoped to have a House of Representatives election at the same time. It has to be borne in mind just what the cost to the taxpayer of an election is. It is an enormous sum. Some $17m can go into an election. Why foist this upon the Australian people when, quite conveniently, the two elections can be held at once? We have heard much discussion, too, during the debate here about electoral reform and the Commonwealth Electoral Act, and of the discussions raised by members of the Opposition too about the unnecessary costs of unnecessary elections-and here they go, giving us a bit of a serve today about daring to do it. As Senator Ray so exactly and nicely pointed out previously in this debate, it is their past record of calling endless early elections that stands and yet they have the gall and the bravado-they are quite cheeky today-to stand here and criticise the Government for political competence.

SPEECH.PARA: So, we must have an election for the half Senate before next year and it is, as members of the Opposition have also argued in the debate about the Commonwealth Electoral Act, the Government's right to choose the time of an election, which is one of the principal arguments against the fixed term with no room for any flexibility or variation. The Government of the day may make the choice because the Government of the day is in business of making wise political choices about when to go to an election so as to retain government. The Government also decides at what time it will introduce its legislation, unashamedly so. So we do not mind the Opposition carping and criticising. We just understand that that is the real world. If Opposition members want to spend some hours today in air time telling the people of Australia what most of them know, good on them.

It is necessary to remind the people of what Senator Chaney thinks of them. He said during his speech that there are intelligent people out there who understand what the issues are but the rest, who are a dimly perceiving part of the electorate, are being snowed. If that is Senator Chaney's perception of the electorate, the dimly perceiving masses, I think that that is a terrible insult to the electorate of Australia. Most of them are very well aware of the unnecessary debate that is proceeding here, and mostly they are not dimly perceiving; they understand very well, and they would understand even better if they were presented with proper topics and proper facts and reasonable arguments , instead of silly wastes of time about how naughty it is for the Government to go early. We can be quite clear that the election has been foisted upon us by the previous Government. This Government's responsible co-operation in regard to that necessary half Senate election is to tie the House of Representatives election to it and, therefore, to avoid the enormous costs to the people of unnecessary extra elections.

I have heard the Opposition say any number of times that we have a Prime Minister who basks in the sun-lamp of popularity, that he is a very vain Prime Minister. Perhaps it is better to bask in the vanity of popular appeal than in the vanity of brown skin from a ray-lamp. If we are talking about vanity, I should like to draw to the Senate's attention a little ditty on which I was reared:
Vanity in women?
What about men?
Think of the peacock.
Was he a hen?

It is a particularly pertinent piece to introduce at this stage. Vanity amongst politicians of the day is not novel, but it seems to me that to be vain about being popular, if that is what the Opposition claims, to be vain about being successful in government and to be vain about the effects of the changes and improvements that one is bringing about in the lot of people in Australia, is a much better thing to be vain about than to be vain about being the Leader of the Opposition and, as Senator Ray so aptly put it, an ineffectual Leader of the Opposition.

The Opposition is very troubled about the prospect of an early election, because it is very clear to Opposition members that they will lose it. They will lose a half Senate election and a House of Representatives election. They are leaderless and without policy. Their attempts at policy are very ineffectual. So instead of producing anything of substance that they might want to tell the people would be reasons for voting for them, they come into this place and give the Government a kick or two about why the Government has been so effective and why so many people support the Government at present and will support it at the next election whenever it is held. Prime Minister Hawke and the Labor Government are unafraid about the timing of the election, given that it must happen within the next 12 to 15 months. There is no worry on the Government side, because the Government can stand on its record in office. It is a short term of office to date. It is a term of great achievement. To date, 210,000 jobs have been created since the Government came to office. Inflation is down by a number of points. Interest rates have fallen and unemployment is down. All of those figures are well known to the electorate, not in terms of the score that appears in the papers but in terms of the changing quality of their lives. They know that they are better off. We have reports of some increase in the consumer-led part of the recovery in the economy at present. One does not get consumer-led recovery unless people have some money to spend.

Senator Collard wanted to attribute it all to the breaking of the drought. That is an exercise in stretching cause and connection. While, of course, the breaking of the drought has contributed to the recovery of the economy to some extent, it has not created jobs in manufacturing and in the city areas nor has it led to the consumer-led recovery that we are seeing. The breaking of the drought is nothing like a total accounting for it. While of course we allow that it contributes to the recovery, it is not the be all and end all of that recovery. It is a silly and trite analysis to attribute the economic recovery to rains falling on the rural sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, is that silly? It has no economic effect?
—I concede that it has a whole lot of economic effect, Senator. I am simply saying that it is not all. It does not create jobs and it does not necessarily bring down unemployment.
—Of course it creates jobs. Good heavens.

—It contributes to some job creation, Senator, but not all. I shall no doubt hear Senator Chaney speaking on this matter on other occasions. I shall remind him from time to time of the groans and grunts that he is contributing at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point to which I should like to allude is the cracks served at the Government by Senator Collard about the consumer price index and the artificial manoeuvering that he claims the Government is undertaking with Medicare. For a start, the Liberal Opposition would know all about that, because it did it five to seven times during the previous seven years. However, this Government will allow that Medicare has an effect on the CPI, which is one of the reasons why, at the same time, it has been indexing pensions and increasing them. But the CPI is not something that is made up by government and it is not a government policy . It is an independently arranged set of figures or appraisals drawn up by economists and, presumably, people in the Treasury. It is from time to time being reviewed. So while the Opposition might want to criticise it, the very newspapers to which the Opposition alluded previously have referred today to the CPI as being an inexact tool, perhaps, but a fairly consistent one over the last few years. It is precisely because of the effects that the CPI allows that one can make the claims that the Opposition makes about the effect of Medicare. The Opposition's claims are right, but they are based on the fact of the CPI and what it does or does not have within it. If it is an inexact tool but a consistent one, it is the best that we have to go on, and it aligns itself fairly well with a measure of the economic recovery in this country. Before the Opposition kicks the Government in the head for the CPI, it should get it clear that the Government is not the total designer of the CPI. If the Opposition wants to change that, why does it not bring forward some legislation? Why does it not propose to the Government that the Government changes what goes into the CPI?

TALK.START.PARA: —They never did anything about it.

—Indeed they did not, except to manoeuvre it, as I said, with their own Medicare or variations on themes throughout the time of the Fraser Government. The last part of this remarkable matter of public importance refers to the deferral of unpopular issues until after the election. I am delighted, Senator Chaney, to be able to read to you from your own words during a debate last night.
—That is a bit unfair.

—It is a bit unfair. I admit that. I rarely get it served up on a platter. Senator Chaney cannot have it both ways. Either the Government is responsible for deferring unpopular issues or the combined effect of the Opposition in this Senate is responsible. Last night Senator Chaney said:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe, for example, that the threat that we made in this Senate-a threat between the Australian Democrats and the Opposition-that we would delay the assets test legislation until February was a threat which has served the people of Australia well.

Those are Senator Chaney's words and he owns the responsibility of a threat that made this Government defer that legislation. He then comes in here and says that the Government is to be castigated for deferring unpopular issues. Senator Chaney cannot have it both ways. I really think that the honourable senator has to admit in this case that it was he who claimed responsibility for deferring some to those issues. It was the honourable senator who last night was pleased to talk about the obstruction, so called, of the combined opposition in this Senate that required the Senate to be reflective and thoughtful in its deliberation upon legislation. If he wants the thought and the deliberation he cannot at the same time critise the Government for deferring legislation when he owns the responsibility for the deferral of some of those decisions. This matter of public importance is a matter of complete nonsense. It is, I think, designed to get air time on a Wednesday for the Senate and I thank the Opposition for allowing me to contribute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President--
—Goodness me, what a shock.
—He used to be a senator here.

—Oh, listen to them. Mr Deputy President, I was going to start by saying of the debate this afternoon from the Government side that I certainly enjoyed Senator Robert Ray. I may disagree with him but he brought a breath of fresh air into the place. But after Senator Crowley had been going for some time I was reminded of some of my readings of George Orwell. I am not referring to Nineteen Eighty-Four or Animal Farm. Back in 1946 he wrote some stuff on the English language. Senator Crowley so much reminded me of it that I went out and got it. Orwell said this, and 1946 is a long time ago:

SPEECH.PARA: Orthodoxy, of whatever colour, seems to demand a lifeless, imitative style. The political dialects to be found in pamphlets, leading articles, manifestos, White Papers and the speeches of under-secretaries do, of course, vary from party to party, but they are all alike in that one almost never finds in them a fresh, vivid, home-made turn of speech. When one watches some tired hack on the platform mechanically repeating the familiar phrases-bestial atrocities, iron heel, bloodstained tyranny, free people of the world, stand shoulder to shoulder -one often has a curious feeling that one is not watching a live human being but some kind of dummy: a feeling which suddenly becomes stronger at moments when the light catches the speaker's spectacles and turns them into blank discs which seem to have no eyes behind them. And this is not altogether fanciful. A speaker who uses that kind of phraseology has gone some distance towards turning himself into a machine. The appropriate noises are coming out of his larynx, but his brain is not involved . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is it in order for Senator Withers to quote from a socialist?
—There is no point of order.
—The great thing about George Orwell was that he was a disillusioned socialist totally disillusioned. He died a bit like Brideshead Revisted.
—There is hope for you yet.
—Hallo, our moustached friend is popping up again.
—At least I get up more than you do.

—Yes, but what the honourable senator says is not worth listening to. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is winding up to an election. We all know when it is going to be held and he is running on Senate obstruction. Senate obstruction has a very familiar ring to me-the awful Senate obstruction. The first time I heard it was from that one time Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam. He made a great show of this. I forget whether it was in early 1973 or early 1974. He went to Victoria and campaigned on Senate obstruction. He said to the Victorian electors: 'Throw out this awful State Liberal Government and vindicate what we are doing for you up in cuckoo-land'. Funnily enough the Australian Labor Party lost that State election.
—That was early 1973.

—It was early 1973. He campaigned on that and we heard all about Senate obstruction then. Of course we heard it all through the double dissolution in 1974 and we heard it all during 1975. I, like Senator Robert Ray, know enough about politics. I heard Mr Fraser also talk about Senate obstructionism. It is not just confined to one Prime Minister of one party or another. I do not know which Prime Minister I am on, the sixth or the seventh, but every Prime Minister since I have been a member of Parliament has complained about Senate obstruction. Mr Hawke is now singing the same tune. Both sides of politics do it and I have heard it from all of them.

SPEECH.PARA: What do Prime Ministers mean by Senate obstruction? What they really mean is what the Senate is doing is exposing a number of things about a government, generally ministerial incompetence, government ineptitude, broken promises and all the rest of it. That is what Senate obstructionism is. That is why governments hate having Bills sent off to committees. They show up all the defects. Governments get things through Cabinet, they get them through their Party meetings, they get them through the lower House with not much attention paid to them at times and then all of a sudden they run into that rock of a Senate committee. I saw this happen under the Whitlam Government with national compensation-the brave new world that was coming-which was condemned out of hand and dropped eventually.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button chaired that committee.

—Senator Button chaired that committee. We saw Senator Murphy's first family law Bill introduced. A Senate committee eventually tidied that up for him. Again the Senate was accused of being obstructive. In recent days we have seen the national crime authority legislation introduced. I do not know whether that will make things better or worse. Was that Senate obstructionism? At least the Government has adopted it. Recently we have had the withholding tax matter which was sent off by the Senate to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations of which Senator Robert Ray and I are both members. I think he would agree with me that by the time that obstructive Senate committee had finished it was a far better administrative tax. I can go on and on and on.

SPEECH.PARA: What fascinates me about the present situation in Australian politics is that everybody in the Labor Party is forgetting their criticism of Malcolm Fraser during 1982-83. The Labor Party members all had a ball during that period. They portrayed Malcolm as devious, opportunistic; he could never stop talking about how he came to power. I do not suppose Bill Hayden can stop talking about how the present Prime Minister came to power. They are just so much alike. In 1982 we heard about the unnecessary election. Why do we not get election talk out of our hair? It is disturbing the economy, it is putting off investment decisions and it is helping to create unemployment. It is funny that that happened only under a Liberal Government but it does not seem to matter that at the moment it is happening under this Government. Of course it was in those days that the Labor Party had this great dream that it had to have fixed term parliaments to keep the bastards honest, the bastards being the Prime Ministers. The Labor Party has rushed into Government and there it is full of all this high minded principle. One of the first things that the present failed Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) came up with was a Bill for an Act to have a referendum on fixed terms but what happened to that? What happened to that great high minded attitude? It was Acton, was it not, who once said that power tends to corrupt and absolute power corrupts absolutely.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was convicted of bribery.

—I would not know about that. Members of the Labor Party do not want to talk about bribery. They have institutionalised corruption certainly in New South Wales and are most likely now doing it in Victoria. What is even more corrupting is the seeking to hold on to power. It corrupts all Prime Ministers in the end and that is what is corrupting the present Government. That is why it is really annoyed about the matter of public importance raised this afternoon. It is exposing that the Government is no better than any other group of politicians in Australia. The best one can say about Bob Hawke is that he is Malcolm Fraser revisited. He is now going to put up the same excuses as Malcolm Fraser put up in 1977 and 1983 for his double dissolution. Is it any wonder it is said that the Australian public has the most cynical attitude to parliamentary democracy in the world?

SPEECH.PARA: I know I have been accused of contributing to that. I do not deny it. I have never walked away from admitting my sins of both omission and commission in politics. I have never paraded myself around this place or anywhere else as some saint. I suppose the Prime Minister has problems with his halo because he most probably has trouble with his hairspray making it somewhat dull. He came to power some 18 months ago on an enormous wave of popularity about bringing Australia together-

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect that you used Brylcreem once.

—Oh yes, but I grew out of that. In my old age I have not gone backwards. When I was a young sailor in bell-bottom pants about 40 years ago I did spend some time before the mirror. It is a sight now that I cannot bear. It is bad enough for my wife, children and colleagues; why should I inflict it upon myself? Of course, the problem with the Government at the moment is that it just hates to be painted as the same as any other government. This is all about its own lost morality.
—Tell us about your protege.

—Senator Robert Ray is trying to make a speech, but I intend to ignore him. Nobody in this Parliament will object to the next House of Representatives being in synchronisation with the Senate. It is a very sensible thing. Nobody objects to that. Those of us on this side of the House who have tried to point out the fraudulent and the deceptive nature of the so-called simultaneous elections have always said the obvious way of fixing the problem is that when the Houses get out of kilter the Reps should be taken out a bit early. This really shows that these sorts of simultaneous election referendums are totally unnecessary. The $64 question which needs to be answered is: Why is the election to be in December 1984?
—You are scared.
—No, I am not scared.
—Come on; you have been honest so far.

—Nothing frightens me. The honourable senator ought to know that . I grew up in the Labor Party when there were real men in it, not the latterly arrived middle class petit bourgeois. My father was in the Labor Party when it was a working class party run by working class men who earned their living and who had some respect for the moral virtues of the family and the decency in doing an honest day's work. You miserable tertiary educated petit bourgeois are a disgrace to the working class and eventually they will turn on you all. You are the sort of people that my father always told me to hold in contempt. Never trust those who attempt to represent the working class when in fact all they wish to do is batten upon them. Nothing is too good for the representatives of the working class, it does not matter whether it is VIP aircraft or anything else! There is nothing wrong with representatives of the working class using VIP aircraft to visit children and grandchildren in remote parts of Australia! This is not the sort of thing that Ben Chifley would have done. Ben Chifley was quite content to live at the Kurrajong, but not the latter day Prime Ministers, including Edward Gough Whitlam.
—From rank Labor men to Labor men of rank.

—That is right. Senator Harradine knows that. Members of the Government would not know that. They would never have heard of that, not this miserable petit bourgeois. They are the curse of the working class and always have been. They are the first people who are generally destroyed. Why is there to be an election in 1984? There is only one reason; that is for party political advantage. Senator Robert Ray asked: 'What is wrong with that?'. I say to Senator Ray: Nothing. I do not mind political parties taking political advantage . That is what politics is all about. One does not win Government to run second. What I do object to is members of the Government whingeing when they are exposed . This is of course one of the reasons why the Premier of Queensland at the moment is coming in for some abuse from the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: What has Mr Bjelke-Petersen done? He has brought publicity to the Government's intention. I have no doubt that Mr Bjelke-Petersen is entitled to exercise his constitutional right and to decide when the half Senate election will be, not some Prime Minister. The most a Prime Minister can do is to ask a Premier to have it on a certain day; he has no right to tell him. Mr Bjelke-Petersen is saying that he will determine it. I have no doubt that he will consider any proper request made to him, but he will not be told when to have it. I do not see anything wrong with that. What the Labor Party is annoyed about is that if Mr Bjelke-Petersen persists in that attitude, and if he is joined by Mr Gray of Tasmania in having Senate elections in their States when they want to have them, this will be a running sore right throughout the election campaign in December. It would be an issue that could not be buried and would be at the forefront of politics. That is why I say that the Australian electorate owes a debt to Mr Bjelke-Petersen for raising the matter. So far no real reason has been given as to why there ought to be an early election apart from political opportunism. If that is the reason, let the Government members say so.
