SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I always follow Senator Withers with some misgivings. I am pleased because I know that he not only kept the audience he had when he began but probably increased it because of the entertaining and forthright speeches he delivers to this place. I am impressed by the refreshing honesty with which he expresses himself. I compliment him on his speech. It is a hard act to follow. He said, with refreshing honesty, that he does not mind political parties taking advantage of situations. Well there at least is one politician who has put the facts on the table. I thought the wording of the matter of public importance brought on by the Liberal Party of Australia was rather quaint. It reads: 'The Government's rush to an unnecessary election this year before economic recovery fades', et cetera. Good heavens! One wonders at any political party, particularly a Liberal Party, talking about rushing to unnecessary elections.

SPEECH.PARA: I have some figures on elections. Up to 1983 there had been 37 elections in Australia in 82 years. That is one election for every two years and three months . But if an election is held in December of this year, which is almost certain, it will mean that there will have been an election every two years and two months. There will have been an election in this country every 26 months on average. But the figures are even more illuminating when it comes to the Liberal Party talking about unnecessary elections. Since 1972-I am presuming an election will be held at the end of this year-we will have had seven elections in this country in 12 years or an election every one year and eight months. If I am right, every one of those seven elections in the last 12 years has been caused directly or indirectly by the Liberal Party. One wonders how Opposition members have the gall to say that this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is rushing to an unnecessary election. Let us have a look at what Mr Hawke did say. In an article in the Australian of 15 February, it is stated:
Mr Hawke gave an undertaking yesterday he would not go to the polls early once the ALP won government.

That was said on 15 February 1983. In fact, he did win government three weeks later. A few weeks after winning government speculation was coming out of his office that it may be necessary for the Australian Labor Party to go to an early election. Senator Withers summed it up perfectly. Political parties do take advantage of situations. We now have statements such as this coming out of Mr Hawke's office, obviously to try to frighten the Liberal Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats: 'Don't you dare knock any legislation back twice; otherwise you will provide a trigger for a double dissolution'. The Prime Minister ought to know that people on this side of the House have shown in the past they do not scare easily.

That threat is not only hollow but also it could bring about something even more irresponsible. If Mr Hawke forces a double dissolution, or uses the trigger that we may or may not provide him with and takes the option of a double dissolution, that will further destabilise this country. As I understand it, although such a situation would be eminently suitable for the Democrats, it would destabilise the country to an extent where, a year and a half further down the track, we would then be looking to another early election. If Mr Hawke wants to live up in any way to the image of a responsible Prime Minister that he wants the electorate to have of him he ought to say now that there will be no double dissolution. I think Senator Withers, with great respect to him, spoke a little with his tongue in his cheek when he said we should not have a House of Representatives election before next June. He has been one of the chief advisers to the Liberal Party over the years-a very efficient adviser-and he ought to know that, if a government is going to the people it does so in November or December. There is no way in the world that a government would go to the people early in the new year when people are receiving their Bankcard accounts after their Christmas spending, when unemployment figures are bad and whatever.

If the Government has to go to an early election-Mr Hawke has to go before the end of June next year because of the half Senate election-then surely we can make some excuse for it to go before the end of this year. However, that does not take away from the fact that all these elections we are having, of which people are sick and tired, mean that the hard issues are being shelved. I have had a very rough estimate taken out-I do not swear by these figures but they are roughly correct-which show, in the last year of the Fraser Government and the first year of the Hawke Government, the time spent by both Houses of Parliament on what one could call the 'non-hard issues'. We have had the colour television set affair, a shocking and scandalous waste of the time of the Parliament. We have had the dairy scandal, the meat scandal, the spy flights over the Franklin River, the Combe-Ivanov affair, the Mick Young affair, the Button versus Kramer affair, the Ian Sinclair affair, et cetera. Those 'fundamental' matters have taken something like 70 per cent of the time of the national Parliament over the last two years.

One would have thought that a Bill of rights would have been a hard issue with which to grapple. Certainly it was promised, and promised vigorously. It has now been shelved until after the election because it is too hard and it might offend certain sectional groups. Fixed-term parliaments were promised; a faithful, vigorous promise made by Mr Hawke in March 1983 when he criticised Mr Fraser's expediency. But that was shelved by the end of 1983 because his hard-headed advisers of a type such as Senator Robert Ray-I mean that as a compliment and not as an insult-said: 'Why should you give up the options that the Liberals have been using for years?' Mr Hawke bowed to expediency.

The question of uranium mining has probably been the most classic sellout of all time. I still find it almost incomprehensible that a political party can win hundreds of thousands of votes on a platform which makes 'an unequivocal commitment to phase out uranium mining' and yet it then mines the largest uranium mine in the world. I cannot understand a political party telling its electors before an election that it will review the alliances with the United States of America and review United States bases in Australia. I cannot understand a political party winning votes, putting fear in the minds of people by saying that the United States base at North West Cape makes Australia a nuclear target. It does. I have elicited that information from the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). He has now admitted that the North West Cape at least is a nuclear target because of the United States presence there. Pine Gap, Nurrungar, Watsonia and Perth in my view, and in the view of some observers, would also be nuclear targets. Yet the Party that campaigned on the issue 'Let us keep Australia out of the nuclear business' has its Foreign Minister standing with his legs astride the largest, most heavily nuclear-armed warship the Americans have, the United States Texas, in the port of Brisbane only a few months ago, saying: 'Is it not a wonderful thing to have our great and powerful friends in Australian ports?' One would not have thought-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is.

—Senator Townley interjects. 'It is'. I respect his view, but Senator Townley did not campaign on the basis of getting the Americans out. The Australian Labor Party did, and that is the difference. I disagree with Senator Townley's view, but at least the Liberal Party has had the honesty to say: 'This is our policy. We welcome the Americans. We welcome United States bases in Australia'. I do not agree with that, but at least the Liberal Party has had the honesty to front up to the people and say: 'That is our policy'. On the other hand, the Labor Party says: 'These bases make us nuclear targets. We must rewrite these policies'. But when the Labor Party comes to power it embraces these policies even more warmly than do the Liberals. I was attracted to Senator Withers's description of Mr Hawke as 'Malcolm Fraser revisited'. I cannot top that. I only hesitate to say that he is now being called the best and most effective conservative Prime Minister since Robert Gordon Menzies. I think both statements are true.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of foreign policy any semblance of morality or principle has now vanished. All has been sacrificed for great and powerful friends. East Timor and human rights abuses in that country have been ignored. Does anybody remember the statements made by Labor spokesmen during the last election campaign about how they would correct the human rights abuses and the tortures in East Timor? We now find Labor Party foreign affairs spokesmen saying that Mr Suharto is a statesman, with no mention being made of abuses of human rights in East Timor. President Marcos still receives our aid so that he can suppress his population.

I have never been one to talk down the economy. I notice that Senator Chaney, on behalf of the Liberal Party, did not do so either today. What he did was sound a prudent warning, and I do the same thing. If we politicians talk down the economy we are doing a disservice. I do think we should not become too euphoric about present indicators. Things do look better now. It would have been disastrous had we continued to decline as we were declining in the latter months of the Fraser Government. We have to remember that some of the causes of this recovery have come about because of the end of the drought. A drought does not end two years running; that is a oncer. It will not occur again, hopefully, for a few years. The United States economy recovered. That is a oncer in a period of five years. That will not happen two years running. Stocks were run down desperately as a result of the 1982-83 recession. Part of this recovery has been due to the building up of stocks again. That will not happen again. All I am doing is saying that these are the sorts of things which the Government ought to be addressing as well as the restructuring of industry.

There has been a lot of talk over the years by both political parties, Liberal and Labor, about the need for lower protection, about the need for long term plans and the phasing out of uneconomic and inefficient industries. Can any honourable senator in this place stand up and say that these constructive things have been done in the restructuring of industry? What about the impact of the silicon chip and the effect the technological revolution is having on our work force? We all know that every day thousands of jobs are being lost that will never be available again. Those jobs are not being lost as a result of bad policies either of the Fraser Government or the Hawke Government. They are being lost because of the technological revolution. Is any long term planning being done to restructure the economy and the society to cover these points? To my knowledge, no.

The Australian Labor Party, when in Opposition when running for office, quite properly made a great deal about child care centres. It gave assurances and promised that a new child care Act would be introduced when it attained government. Nothing has been done. I will speak for one moment about this question of child care. All the reading that I have done indicates that with children the first three or four years of life are the formative years; the personality is virtually established and things such as ambition, character, the will to survive, the will to fight one's surroundings and the ability to get on with one's fellow human beings are all formed in those early years. What we middle class politicians do is to judge all children by the standards by which we raise our own. We assume that all children have the happy home, the meals-we assume that they do not suffer hunger-and the good education of our own. Tragically, that is not true. We middle class politicians must assume that there are a great number of children in Australia who are deprived of those things through no fault of their own. It is the responsibility of governments to step in and assist in that direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would first of all like to pass a few comments on Senator Chipp's remarks. Senator Chipp said that Senator Chaney and the Opposition had not attempted to talk down the economy. However, if one reads very carefully the subject of the matter of public importance it shows very clearly what the Opposition is doing. The Opposition is making a prediction of gloom and setting out, in terms of the wording of the matter of public importance, a downturn in the economy. I will firstly say something about the historical points relating to the half Senate election. Senator Chipp made some of these points earlier. A half Senate election has to be held by late April or early May next year at the latest to allow sufficient time for the vote to be counted and completed before the newly elected senators can take their place by 1 July 1985. Section 13 of the Constitution states that a half Senate election must be held in the 12 months prior to the expiry of the senators' terms. In other words, we are now in a pre- election period. Current short term senators' terms expire on 30 June 1985. Traditionally, elections in Australia have been held either late in the year or very early in the year, presumably to take advantage of the warmer weather. Since Federation there have been elections for half the Senate and the House of Representatives together on 22 occasions. In 83 years there have been only five occasions when politicians have been silly and irresponsible enough to commit the taxpayers to the expense and inconvenience of holding a half Senate election alone. I suppose when we say that we need to look at the cost of a half Senate election. A half Senate election in December combined with an election for the House of Representatives will cost the taxpayer something in the vicinity of $ 30m. A half Senate election held alone in April next year will cost the taxpayer about $25m to $26m, with the prospect of another election for the House of Representatives some 10 months later at the same price.

When one talks about economy of scale, surely one should consider very carefully the holding of joint elections so that the extra cost is not foisted on the Australian electorate. DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT INCENTIVES BOARD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

While I applaud the significant contribution by the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board on the importance of developing new technology and new products and of being internationally competitive in producing those products, there is nevertheless a fundamental gap in not having a body or institution to bridge the gulf between research and its commercial application. Australia could well adopt a scheme along similar lines to the Ideas Corporation from Ontario, Canada, where the intention is in a tangible way to help innovations succeed commercially and to improve the diffusion of new technology into industry. This Ideas Corporation, through its specialised substructures of micro-electronics, information technology, mechanics and automation, biological and chemical specialities, develops viable business organisations capable of competing successfully in a commercial environment with rewards and incentives designed to draw top and specialised men in the fields of marketing, engineering, commerce, et cetera. Although venture capital is initially provided by the Government and apportioned to projects, the intention is that in time these companies will be sold off to provide an increased capital fund through which to provide for innovations.

The Ideas Corporation can also act as a licensing broker for innovation. So often people developing new projects lack a knowledge of industrial law, including the necessity to patent the invention in such a manner that the rewards of the innovation can flow to the appropriate people. Over the years Australia has had a good record of original research, but it lacks the capacity to develop commercial application of this research. I have passed on the concept of the Ideas Corporation, together with a great deal of associated literature, to Mr Barry Jones, the Federal Minister for Science and Technology. I am glad that his initial reaction was to meet the proposal with a degree of enthusiasm. I have also sent the same information to my State colleague, the Honourable Neil Robson, the Tasmanian Minister for Industrial Development. I take this opportunity to thank the President of the Ideas Corporation, Dr B. E. St John, who is a PhD graduate from Australia, for the time he took to explain the workings of the Ideas Corporation when I recently met with him in Toronto, Canada.

SPEECH.PARA: We owe a great deal to the people who developed the basic infrastructure of this country-its roads, its railways, its sewerage works, its cities and the like-and who did so with an idealistic view towards the future. It is worth noting in passing that it appears that we are having great difficulty now in even maintaining sensibly the great resources which they built . Is it to be our role, as a generation, to cast aside that kind of responsibility of thinking for the future and say that as long as we keep going quite selfishly within our lifetime and there are enough things for us we do not care what hardships or depravations future generations must have?

I raise these points because when we look at it that way I think it is suggested strongly-this is what the Australian Democrats believe as a matter of fundamental faith-that the economics of alternative energy are not the only factor to be taken into account. The Democrats believe that we should be preparing adequately now for a sustainable society and that the community wants us to be preparing now for a sustainable society. These things are very well understood in the community. I often wonder, Mr Deputy President, whether the community does not understand them better than this place understands them. It would not be the only thing about which it had a better understanding. So we should be preparing now for that sustainable society; the community is ready to accept that along with the slight additional cost it would incur. That, of course, can be done only if there is adequate incentive for research into the permanently renewable energy resources.

The long run might not even be that long. The work in solar energy must be done. This is, of course, happening extensively overseas, but not here in Australia, which should be the most suitable country for this kind of advanced research.

One of the most vital areas of renewable energy resource research is, of course , solar technology. I notice that the report shows that solar technology research received only 1.7 per cent of sunrise industries projects grants for 1982-83. This seems, to the Australian Democrats, to be part of the general, deplorable trend away from government funding of renewable energy research. That comment is the subject of a statement in today's Canberra Times. I will read it, because I think it ought to be on the record:
The Northern Territory Government was engaged in a 'cold war' against the Aboriginal people, the Central Land Council said in its third annual report tabled in Parliament yesterday.

It said the Northern Territory Government, led by the Chief Minister, Mr Everingham, had continued its attack on the legislation-on which Aboriginal people relied to keep their law-and waging a propaganda battle against sacred sites.

Of course, the propaganda battle was dealt with in a publication entitled 'A Question of Justice' which was put out by the Central Land Council in an attempt to meet some of the massive publicity mounted by the Northern Territory Government in seeking support for its package. It spoke of the package of the Northern Territory Government as being divisive. The report continued:

The report contains a quote which is well worth reading. I think most Territorians, particularly those who have been in the Territory for some time, find it very distasteful when actions are taken by a government of a State or Territory which are designed to create divisions between black and white. That is certainly what has happened in the Northern Territory. After years of living in a multicultural society of black and white and other colours, and other ethnic groups, the Government has attempted to create divisions. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am continuing the remarks I made in the chamber yesterday on this most important report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I welcome the opportunity to continue with some comment about this most important matter. The Senate does have before it the report of the special investigation into the National Crimes Authority Bill. It is special in the sense that the number of members on the Standing Committee was increased by two people, Senator Chipp and me, to investigate this matter. There has been some discussion about whether that was a good or a bad thing but there is no doubt that the report is an excellent one and it will be of benefit to the Government as the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) so gracefully said in this chamber yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: The main thrust of the inquiry highlights the tension that we had to deal with, in fact that any government has to deal with, when confronting the issue of the establishment of a National Crime Authority. There is a very real tension to be balanced or addressed between the civil liberties of the Australian people and the need for sufficient investigatory powers to combat and reduce, if not stamp out, organised crime in this country. We do have the benefit of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and of other royal commissions too but certainly of the Costigan Commission's great contribution, apart from the specific issues it dealt with. The great contribution of the Costigan Royal Commission was to draw the attention of the Australian people to the existence of very extensive organised crime in this country. I think it was something of a shock to the Australian people to realise just how extensive organised crime had become in this country. Both the previous Government and the present Government have seen the need to deal with this matter by the establishment of a permanent or ongoing authority, something that does not have the same characteristic as a royal commission. I think it is important to stress that royal commissions have special terms of reference, a specific life and very special powers attached to them.

The report has recommended-it was certainly one that I spoke against-that the Authority continue with the name Authority rather than adopt the recommendation of the majority report that it be called a commission principally because I think it is important to highlight the difference between a commission, a royal commission and the existence of the powers in an ongoing National Crimes Authority. The Authority has a very different life expectancy. It has very different powers and it has a different role. It is a law enforcement agency and much more akin to that. In this case it is proposed that it be granted very special powers within the terms of reference. However, it is quite unlike a royal commission and it is important to make that distinction very clear. It is for that reason, of course, that I supported the notion that the organisation be called an authority and not a commission so there is no possibility of any confusion.

The other point I wish to address briefly is the need for public accountability of the Authority and I alluded to that in a small dissenting report. I would like to see the continuation of the presence in the National Crime Authority Bill 1983 of the role for the Ombudsman and the role for a judicial audit or something approximating that. I feel that I may have been the only member of the Committee who felt very happy that the Ombudsman had a role in the overview and analysis of the functions of the National Crime Authority. I see the Ombudsman as a person who has become very widely accepted in the community as a representative or supporter of the ordinary citizen, particularly a person taking up the cudgels against bureaucracies, institutions or the weight of anachronistic regulations. The Ombudsman has become well accepted by the ordinary citizen in the community. I feel though that the Ombudsman is still doing battle to be taken seriously in a world populated by lawyers.

I do not wish to suggest what words the Bill should provide by way of advising what the Ombudsman's role would be. Certainly on occasions the Ombudsman may be able to take action on behalf of an individual citizen who has complaints against the actions or behaviour of the Authority but I also feel the Ombudsman could have a role of overview, the larger review analysis of the Authority's work in the course of its year's operations. However, how that matter is addressed finally is not for me to decide. I simply feel it is important to say that I support the presence of the Ombudsman's role in the Authority. It is an important one and it is principally one of spokesman for the ordinary person in the community.

The other dimension of accountability is referred to in the Bill as requiring a judicial audit. There was much discussion in the course of the Committee about whether or not such a judicial audit would be effective and/or effectual. Certainly I am happy with the proposed changes in the Bill that any grievances a person wants to bring against actions of the Authority might be better dealt with by summary applications to a judge. I have no argument with that proposed recommendation as a change to the Bill. However, I still support the need for some external body or bodies to overview, to review and to do an external analysis of the year's performance. The Authority itself will be required to produce an annual report. Of course that is to be commended and I strongly support the recommendations supporting that in the report of the Senate Committee. I feel it is also important that this be balanced by an external annual report.

Some people have suggested to me that I am using the word audit non- specifically or incorrectly. I think that audit might be a very appropriate word . There needs to be some external body looking at the functions and the operations of the Authority. These would include, no doubt, the economic analysis, how much it spends, how many people are working in the Authority and what those people have been employed to do. But more importantly it would look at the terms of reference that the Authority has accepted or taken on for itself during the year and how those terms of reference are being pursued or dealt with . I feel that an authority such as this which will be provided with the extraordinary powers that it will be given under the terms of reference does need to have a clear understanding that it has to be publicly accountable. I therefore support the retention of the judicial audit. Maybe the words in the Bill would be somewhat changed but I still feel the principle of public accountability under that term should remain.

Finally, the Parliament in its ordinary operations will also be able to examine the functions of the Authority quite adequately without the establishment of any special parliamentary or Senate committee to overview or review the work of the Authority. It is my opinion that with the annual report from the Authority, perhaps a report from the Ombudsman and the judicial audit, the Parliament, in reading those reports and checking through them, would have more than sufficient occasion and opportunity to check publicly and review the functions of the most important organisation that is proposed to be established, that is the National Crime Authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the motion that the Senate take note of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs relating to the National Crime Authority Bill 1983. Firstly, I most sincerely congratulate the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Michael Tate from Tasmania, on an excellent job. In my view he brought the Committee together extremely well. He had an enormous input into the writing of the report and generally he did an excellent job. When I say 'generally' I mean in all. I have no criticisms at all of Senator Tate's performance as Chairman of the Committee. It was a pleasure to work with him.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to pay a tribute to my colleagues. There were four members of the Australian Labor Party, three members of the Opposition and Senator Chipp from the Australian Democrats. We worked together very well as a team. Some of us had not worked together previously. Two additional committee members were appointed for this report. I pay a tribute and a compliment to the staff for their work. I would also like to pay a tribute to those people who made submissions. There were nearly 40 written submissions. A large number of witnesses came before the Committee. It was clear that the people who made submissions and the witnesses who came before the Committee had put an enormous amount of work into considering the evidence that they gave to us and the submissions they made. People go out of their way to help Senate committees.

The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs has clearly shown the enormous value and importance of Senate committees to the national Parliament. Mr Deputy President, I must say with you in the Chair that I see much merit in important pieces of legislation always being referred to Senate committees for their consideration. In this particular case the report contains some 60 recommendations. Two members of the team could not agree to two recommendations, I could not agree to one recommendation and Senator Missen could not agree to six recommendations. So really seven people agreed to 58 recommendations. That is an enormous indication of unanimity and across the board multi-party thinking. This is the sort of thing that goes on in Senate committees that so many of us have been talking about for so long. I wish people would understand the enormous value of referring legislation to Senate committees for their consideration and not think of it as, in some way, a delaying tactic. What does it matter if for some reason or other a Bill is delayed for a couple of months, perhaps even six months, if as a result of that delay the legislation is as vastly improved as this legislation has been? There is no doubt about that. The unanimous report is that the Bill, as originally presented to the Senate, was totally inadequate. That has been acknowledged by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) who has accepted the report. He indicated that in the initial stages of his examination of the report he cannot see any reason why the Government cannot go along with it.

I have to be very brief in referring to the detail of the report because I have only a limited time to speak on this matter this evening, but I would like to say that I go along very much with what Senator Hill had to say last night. I thoroughly approve of his remarks. I thought the Chairman's tabling statement was excellent. In the National Crime Authority we are balancing the national interest of the majority of the people of Australia against the individual's civil liberties and rights. This is a matter of fine balance and of great concern to all parliamentarians and indeed to people right around the nation. It was clear to us from the very early stages that the information we received from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and from Mr Redlich that so-called organised crime in Australia is a matter of grave concern and should be a matter of grave concern to the people of this nation. I use the words 'organised crime', but I think Mr Hampson, QC, expressed it as 'a running series of conspiracies'. I think that is probably the true situation because different groupings of people come together to involve themselves in different criminal activities.

It is interesting to note that there might be about 2,000 major criminals around the nation. That was one estimate which was given to us. These people spend their entire lives organising the raising of revenue in some way which is illegal. It seems as if once they are involved in one series of criminal activities they involve themselves in others. It might be drugs, tax evasion, arson, murder or bank robberies. They get involved in all of these things. Some of them are for specific purposes. For example, people might rob banks in order to raise money so that they can buy their way into the next syndicate bringing hard drugs into the country. In other words, they raise money so that they can involve themselves in another criminal activity.

We will never be able to eliminate this, but suppression must be the aim of this Authority. Suppression can be carried out in two ways: Firstly, by prosecution, which is the way most people think of it. On examination, it became clear that prosecution is not the be all and end all because we were informed of people who, on being sent to gaol, transferred their office to gaol. Once they got involved, so long as they had their funds outside their money was the important thing. One of the most significant things about this Bill is that we recommend civil proceedings be taken and taken rapidly using Mareva injunctions to try to deprive these people of their funds as quickly as possible. The deprivation of funds will suppress this so-called organised crime far quicker than the prosecutions which take months before ultimately people are locked up in gaol. Once they are locked up in gaol they may still continue with their work .

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you get their funds from them?

—I am sorry; I have got only three minutes left. Mr Redlich said one thing which is of major importance: It does not matter how much we disagree with the formation of a National Crime Authority, when we see the lack of co- operation among the prosecuting and investigating branches of the Federal Government and State governments and the Federal and State police forces we will realise the need for co-operation and establish an authority for the purpose of co-operation. That is really what we are proposing with the general level of functions of this Authority. Once it moves into its special level of functions it has all sorts of other coercive powers.

SPEECH.PARA: I have heard people expressing worry about the disclosure of tax records. Approximately 2,000 or 3,000 people around the nation who are involved in these activities frankly do not file tax returns; legitimate people file tax returns. They do not have to worry about the powers which this Authority might have over their tax returns. We are talking about people who do not bother to file tax returns. Filing of tax returns is for the suckers! These people are involved in criminal activities, they assume different names and involve themselves in fake companies. They are not involved in the legitimate business transactions of normal people of this nation.

One of my colleagues indicated that he thought this Authority was still a toothless tiger. This Authority, under this proposal, is far from a toothless tiger. This Authority, under our proposals, will have enormous powers, which I hope it will be able to exercise to the benefit of this nation. I hope the Attorney-General does pay some due regard to my dissenting report because I do believe that although it is a matter of legal technicality it is of great importance to the future of the Authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs I also rise to speak to the report . Like Senator Lewis and every other speaker before me on this matter I commence by congratulating Senator Tate for the way in which he handled the Committee's procedures and conducted this inquiry. It has been a difficult inquiry, one that has been forced on the Committee in terms of the time that was available to it. It is one that canvassed quite a number of issues, some of them of very deep complexity. As Senator Lewis mentioned, Senator Tate managed to bring the Committee together in such a way that we have been able to agree on substantially all the 65 recommendations. Of those, only a handful were not agreed to in one way or another by individual members of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I must also congratulate and thank the Committee secretariat together with the barrister charged to work with us, Mr John Lord, from the Melbourne bar. Their work was extremely helpful. They also had to work under extreme difficulty, working both at weekends and late at night. The amount of work that they contributed should also be placed on record. The other people involved in the Committee who should also be acknowledged are those who put time, effort and thought into the preparation of submissions. We had over 40 submissions some of which were of great length. Some people spent a substantial amount of time with the Committee assisting it to reach its conclusions. Of those, none were more co -operative than Mr Redlich, the Special Prosecutor, and Mr Costigan and his staff who gave us an insight into how an authority such as this can operate. Their assistance ought to be recorded.

As has been mentioned, the National Crime Authority Bill 1983 is a response to a major problem in Australian society. It canvasses all parts of society, whether it involves the social effects of organised crime, whether it relates to the impact on loss of tax revenue or whether it impinges on law enforcement agencies and corruption therein. Governments over the years have had the responsibility to respond to this problem but have not done so. As Senator Lewis mentioned, over the last number of years organised crime has blossomed.

I have been fortunate enough to get a copy of a report written by Mr Cusack, commissioned by the Victorian Government in 1954, on activities that took place in Victoria in 1954; the then so-called Victorian market murders. It is interesting to go back to the recommendations of Mr Cusack, a person who was brought over from America to advise the then Victorian Government on organised crime and on ways to tackle it. He responded in a number of ways. But the problems that he highlighted then are those that are very much relevant now. He recognised that there was a lack of co-ordination in government response to organised crime. He suggested then that a special extortion squad should be formed, that the Special Branch of the Victorian Police should have an intelligence gathering role and that a criminal intelligence unit should also be set up to assist the operational commands in detecting or suppressing organised crime.

Essentially, that was the first time in Australia that there had been recognition of the fact that organised crime was of such a nature that it could not be adequately handled by conventional law enforcement methods. Mr Cusack recognised the necessity for specialist training, a specialist approach and an intelligence gathering role in respect of organised crime as distinct from the conventional role of responding to individual offences. It is interesting to note that the list of recommendations he made-somewhere in the vicinity of 15 or 20-are very much those that could well be the core of the Government's response, both in respect to the National Crimes Authority Bill and the response of the previous Federal Government when it put up its proposal. Since then there have been a number of inquiries-in fact there have been eight as the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) indicated to me this week in reply to a question on notice-on different aspects of organised crime in this country ranging over the last 20 years. But substantially the last seven inquiries have been since 1974. This is an indication of the growing nature of the problem.

At the outset of the debate on the establishment of the National Crime Authority Bill I raised my doubts about the ability of such a response to handle adequately the problem. I was extremely sceptical about it. I am pleased to say that, like other honourable senators involved in this inquiry, the process of education that I have gone through has been a very healthy one. I still do not resile from the fact that I have some doubts about the effectiveness of the organisation, but I accept fully that there is a need for an effective co- ordinating body of criminal intelligence. This body is one that has the greatest possibility of meeting the problem.

The report that has been publicised has been claimed as being one that will strengthen the Authority. That is so. I believe that, in the overwhelming number of its recommendations, it makes for more effective authority but, in doing so, does not necessarily detract from or impinge upon individual civil liberties. It is a balance between expanding the areas of operation of the Authority but, at the same time, in some parts it acknowledges that an individual's rights should be protected. This is done in a number of areas. The Committee, in recommending that the Authority be graded towards a prosecutional role, directs the Authority in the future to act in those areas of utmost priority and need. The acceptance by the Committee of the derivative use exemption to self-incrimination is also extremely important.

I made a number of comments in my minority report about my attitude to crime and the reasons for organised crime flourishing. I made the point that all those unenforceable social laws that act as the incubator for organised crime ought to be tackled by government in somewhat of a radical way in order that a major part of the community can be detached from the web of organised crime. When we attempt to enforce unenforceable laws it leads to bribery, corruption and the establishment of avenues to facilitate organised crime. That is the web that ensnares thousands of Australians, willingly or unwillingly. I believe that those laws ought to be re-assessed. My minority report deals with that point in detail.

A point about which I was also concerned, as was Senator Crowley, was the question of accountability. We are setting up an authority which has the potential to act excessively in terms of its legislative charter. Mr Justice Kirby, in his contribution to the National Crimes Commission Conference approximately a year ago, made the point that we stand the risk of creating either the cosmetics of an ineffective agency or a too powerful institution unaccountable in practice to the courts or to our democratic institutions. I believe that there is a danger there. The Government, in its proposal to have a judicial audit of the Authority, as well as having the Authority susceptible to Ombudsman purview, is proposing a mechanism which may or may not be effective but which offers the only chance of an effective overview of this Authority. I think it is necessary, given the types of powers and functions the Authority is to have, to have this sort of overview mechanism. I note that the majority has recommended an alternative system but I think the conventional system will be adequate for the particular task. I think my time is very well up. Any other points that I have to make I will make in the course of the debate when the Bill comes before the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs relates to the National Crime Authority Bill introduced by the Hawke Government and debated extensively in this chamber quite some months ago. In essence the Committee was asked to look at the Bill and decide whether it would be effective in carrying out the concept of a national crime authority.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all I commend the Committee. I commend the Chairman of the Committee for a very difficult task. I commend all members of the Committee for doing one of the most significant jobs that the Senate can do. This Senate, if it is anything, as a House of review functions at its best in the committee system when it takes a Bill apart and reports back. It functions at its best in a bipartisan system where it is willing, after considerable debate-we had this type of debate on the Bill, where great differences were revealed by both sides- and after sifting through material, to come to some unity and comity of view on great matters. It has done so I think on nearly 60 recommendations, all of which are of particular interest. It is very well worth stating, as other honourable senators have done earlier, that those who see the Senate as obstructing because it uses the numbers of its Opposition and minority parties to achieve a purpose, should reflect upon the very great value of such a venture when it brings to the attention of the community outside and to the Parliament a committee report of such value as this. This is not the first such report; it is one of very many. It represents the very life blood of the Senate. I repeat: I commend all members of the Committee.

In the course of the past debate on the Bill it was made clear by the Opposition that we had grave doubts about the effectiveness of the Bill as it presently exists. It was a Bill that sought to replace a piece of legislation introduced by the Fraser Goverment and passed through the Parliament but not implemented. The real question was whether the Bill could do its job. A number of major points were made. One point I had clearly in mind was whether the Bill could ever function if the essential veto lay with the States. This was not only on matters that concerned the States themselves but also on matters that were entirely within the Commonwealth sovereignty. Quite clearly when that was examined it was acknowledged that that would be a fundamental defect of the system. It was concluded that the Commonwealth had to be given powers of its own initiative within its own jurisdiction to act without the restraint or confinement of the States in such matters. Obviously there has to be consultation with the States; that is foreseen.

One of the other matters I raised here related to the restriction on the subjects of reference in that there were certain specified offences and nothing less than a maximum, I think, of three years imprisonment for such offences. Of course, the world knew that in the past the pursuit of great organised crime had started with the pursuit of money through what were relatively minor offences. I do not know that the Al Capone taxation avoidance was a minor offence but it is worth remembering that in fact that arch criminal of world notoriety was caught in the end by pursuit through the taxation system. Quite clearly one of the things the Committee had to address itself to was whether the limitations in the Bill ought to remain. As I understand the position, it was decided that they should not. The Committee has approached quite a number of subjects on that basis.

I believe that whilst many of us may have points of difference to raise when we see the amended Bill we would agree that what the report has done has been very substantially to improve an ineffectual Bill. Some of us would like to see more. While I do not necessarily agree with any of the dissenting reports I commend them because they are a challenge to us to examine the ideas and thinking behind them. I believe that the report itself, apart from its recommendations, is an educative process for the community as a whole. I have now managed to read the report several times and am the better for reading it. I will be the better still for reading the volume of evidence that came before the Committee. I commend to all honourable senators that they at least try to peruse the evidence before we have an amended Bill back in the Senate.

Great questions were raised by the Committee. These questions stimulate thought ; for example, the question of the role on the one hand of intelligence gathering and on the other hand of the getting of substantive evidence for the courts. What would be the balance between these two? How do the authorities go about this matter? I think Committee members have come to a basic sensible conclusion. In any case they have done what I think is the job of a Senate committee. They have created a yeasting in our minds of thought on this matter. Therefore, on balance whilst I would have preferred to have had considerably longer to study the matter I certainly believe that a number of the major matters have been confronted.

I am a little puzzled about one point. I made a critical comment as to the construction of the Authority and as to the nature, particularly any ex-officio nature, of persons who would be members of the Authority. I felt there would be some subjective involvement back to some sponsors. For example, without reflecting on the police, I felt there was not a need for such a subjective judgment at all. I felt that an authority should be composed of persons who owe nothing to patronage; I use the word 'patronage' in its better sense. I see quite a number of such issues that need to be examined in relation to this matter.

I think that we will need to look very carefully at how we define organised crime so that we do not restrict the pursuit of something which may look like a net but which has only one obvious alleged offender to start with. This worries me. I would need to go back to the original Bill to look at the definitions. In any case, in all fairness I should say that the point we have arrived at now is so much the richer and the more rewarding than the point we were at before we started on this journey.

As I understand it, the Government intends to adopt the Committee's report. I commend the Government for that. In the very heat of debate in this chamber partisan positions have been taken. It is a good thing to know that from time to time we can put aside our partisanship and get on with the job of sharing of bipartisan views. In brief, in the very limited time that is possible in the discussion on committees' reports, I repeat that the report is a good one in the time that was available. I congratulate those who made their submissions because they were very difficult submissions to make. I thank all members of the Senate Committee for the work they have done. I hope that the Government will, with reasonable expedition, seek to bring before us an amended Bill. There is a great urgency in Australia for an effective national crime authority to get on with the job. A half a dozen royal commissions have thrown up the massive evidence in this regard and revealed the massive urgency of such an authority. It is time we got on with the job. Most importantly it is time that we had an instrument that is effective and does not seriously breach civil liberties. That is a concept that the Committee dealt with. I think the Committee has done well, although I would have some particular criticisms. I thank the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on the National Crime Authority Bill 1983. In doing so I join all other honourable senators who have spoken in this debate in commending the quality of the report. The report reads extremely well. It is certainly not a dry document. It is very succinct in expression and clear in the portrayal of complex issues. It is a report that lay people can come to grips with very easily. They can come to understand quite complex questions. The honourable senators on the Committee who have contributed to the report also, I believe, deserve the sincere thanks of the Senate for the role they played in bringing this document forward, as of course do the Senate staff who assisted in the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been said by all other honourable senators who have spoken on this report this afternoon that the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Tate, has played a vital role and has involved himself deeply in the construction of the report and the conduct of the hearings. My experience of Senator Tate in the chair of this Committee is that he performs his role judiciously, astutely and in the responsible way we have come to expect from his performance in this House .

The contribution of the witnesses also requires some comment. The list of people who appeared before the Committee, and indeed the organisations and individuals who put submissions to it, reads almost like a Who's Who of legal experts in criminal law and all the various organisations that have a rightful point of view on that subject. Quite clearly they have given their time generously and their expertise fulsomely. I believe that without that very strong support from the experts in the field the Committee would not have been able to present such a report. I think the report reflects extremely well upon the role of committees of the Senate. A number of comments about that have been made by various honourable senators in their contributions. I support all those comments. For me it has been an experience to see a committee start with a reference and end with a report. I believe that has broadened my horizon quite a bit in understanding the role, importance and significance of what Senate committees can do.

I now turn to the report itself. The first comment that has to be made is that the report deals with a problem in Australian society of horrendous dimensions. In this country criminal organisations and organised crime are a major problem. It is a problem that has defied other remedy until this point. Many of the honourable senators who spoke earlier in this debate, particularly Senator Crowley, Senator Lewis and Senator Bolkus, spoke about aspects of the report and removed from me the obligation to go into some detail about them. I believe that the role of the Committee that inquired into that legislation was to find the necessary balance between the very real need to detect and suppress organised crime in this country while at the same time protecting the civil liberties of people in our community and ensuring that by protecting those civil liberties people are able to do things properly and rightly, as they should be able to in a democratic society.

As I said earlier, the report in fact has come up with many recommendations which would improve upon the legislation. I know that the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) has indicated his willingness to consider those favourably . It is important in the intelligence gathering role of the commission or authority-'commission' is the recommended title in the report-that it be able, as an ordinary function of its role and of its own volition, to investigate matters, collect and analyse information and inform itself on all relevant criminal activity so that it is able to receive references and also initiate recommendations for references. It should be able to do that without the granting of an authority or without necessarily having to consult the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence.

It is important that it have that role of being able in the ordinary course of events to initiate information gathering; so that there is prima facie evidence to justify specific references or to help frame specific investigations. It is important that there be a body of monitored information which enables the money trail to be followed much more quickly and so that recommendations on law reform that might issue from the authority or commission can so issue. At pages 27 and 30 of the report references are made to the need of the authority or commission to be able to obtain information from other government bodies and government records, specifically tax. I think that a reading of that section of the report would repay anyone handsomely.

In the debate this afternoon some comment has been made by various honourable senators about the role of judicial audit. I think that, quite clearly, a body such as this requires absolute scrutiny at all times to ensure that civil liberties are protected while its role is in fact made successful in suppressing organised crime. But whether a judicial audit is an effective way of doing that is a matter for proper debate. It is my view that the work of such an authority or commission is so immense, its activities would be so complex, that it is not possible, with the best will in the world and the greatest faith and sincerity, accurately to conduct an effective judicial audit of all of its aspects. To propose the idea of judicial audit is to suggest in the minds of the community that there is a process going on which in reality cannot be achieved. Therefore, I think it is wrong to suggest judicial audit and it is right for this parliament and for the community at large to keep a constant weather eye cocked to the activities of the authority or commission and to make sure that it fulfils its purpose. Senator Bolkus said a number of things about derivative use protections against self-incrimination. Again, I think a reading of that section of the report would repay anyone handsomely and I commend such a reading to the community.

I have to remark on one other matter. Yestereday, in debate on the report-this is recorded at page 1394 of the Senate Hansard-Senator Missen made some remarks concerning me and my role in this industry. I think that I should say something about those remarks as the matter has been raised in the chamber. The first comment I make is that I respect absolutely the integrity of Senator Missen and his intent. I do not regard the remarks he made as politically motivated in the sense of trying to best one person against another. I consider that he is concerned, as he sees it, about the role of the Committee. If he is concerned, as clearly he is, in my view he is right to come forward and say so publicly. I do not in any sense criticse him for doing that.

However, the fact that he has raised the matter has caused me to examine the purport of his remarks and my role in terms of this Committee. I think in the end it comes down to whether I can sincerely and conscienciously be of the view that rightly my name should appear on the report. That seems to me to be an act of private conscience. I believe I have attended as best I can to obtaining a full understanding of the activities of the Committee by reading the transcripts and considering the evidence. Therefore, while Senator Missen, if he considers it a concern, is right to raise the matter, I am right to say that in those circumstances I do not think it correct that my name should not appear, because I believe I undertook a genuine and conscientious consideration of the issues and can rightly append my name to the report. I commend the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief because we are rapidly running out of time and because Senator Tate, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, wishes to say a few words before we finish this evening, which I think is appropriate. As a senator who did not take part in the original debate last year nor was a member of the Committee, I feel freer than probably many members of the Committee to laud the type of work they have done and also to put into perspective what the Senate is doing in this exercise. Bills that come into this place are prepared by the bureaucracies attached to the various Ministers and indeed in many ways the Government has a minimal input into those pieces of legislation. When one reads through this report one sees the unique series of skills that people elected to this place manage to bring to bear on something that is going to affect other people in the community. In other words, the operation of the democratic process is probably now seen only in these types of operations and is rarely seen in operation in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The committees are probably the successor to a genuinely democratic chamber. As are other senators, I am called upon to serve upon a number of committees. I can say that all the committees on which I serve are also conducted in such a way that people, no matter what political party they belong to, bring their unique characteristics, knowledge and skills to bear on what is before them. When the reports come to the Senate fairly obviously political party positions tend to take over and people are bludgeoned or accept the positions dictated to them by the party hierarchies, but when one looks at a report one is looking at the product of individual members of the Senate. While in many debates we tend to denigrate one another as part of the political process, it is useful from time to time to stand back and to look at the high quality work which is able to be produced by senators. It is a pity that this type of work is not given greater publicity and that much more attention is not paid to it by the various media services.

The only other point I wish to raise is one that has concerned me in discussions I have had with police forces in my State and with individual members of police forces; that is, that the crimes commission, when it operates, will be able to operate probably only as efficiently as its support by the State police forces allows. I notice that the Committee recomends specifically that, as a matter of urgency, legislation should be enacted which would encourage the States to have parallel legislation but that the Committee has also recommended that the crimes commission be able to pursue its activities if a State does not wish to come in, provided the crime in question goes over State boundaries. I believe that is an effective compromise. Nevertheless, one must still be concerned that the realities of the matter are that the State police forces in Australia are really the best mechanisms for combating crime. The extent to which those State police forces will be able to work with the national crimes commission, I believe, is the extent to which the national crimes commission will be effective. I am pleased that the recommendations seek to encourage the States to work with the national crimes commission so that together they will be able to solve what is undoubtedly a massive and emerging problem in Australia. In conclusion, I hope once again that, in organising the way in which we do our business, we may look more towards committees as an effective and essential element in the democratic process in the years ahead and, given the strength of the political parties, as possibly the only area where democracy can really flourish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-As the mover of the motion, I believe I am concluding this debate on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on the National Crimes Authority Bill. In the three or four minutes allowed to me I simply wish to thank those honourable senators who have made generous remarks about the work of the Committee. I believe their remarks are justified, as I expect those who get the chance to read the report in succeeding days will be able to conclude that there was no shirking of some very difficult issues by this Committee in its deliberations. I believe we have discharged in a way which should satisfy the Senate the obligation placed upon us, with undue time constraints, to report in a way which will enable this chamber to agree to the passage of legislation to establish a new authority within the Australian community, an authority vested not only with some ordinary powers but also with some quite extraordinary ones to enable it to engage in the fight against organised crime and official corruption.
—Did you say 'undue' constraints of time?

—Yes, we had to report by 1 May. The essence of our report is that any authority to be established ought to be as free as possible from political directives, intervention or constraints. To that end we have devised a mechanism whereby we distinguish two levels of the authority's operation. One is the ordinary level whereby it can gather information, compile intelligence, establish task forces, co-ordinate activities between Federal and State law enforcement and investigating agencies and, most particularly, require the co- operation and assistance of other Federal departments and agencies. We found throughout the evidence we received that it was the protection of turf and the lack of co-ordination and co-operation between various departments and agencies at the Commonwealth level and at the Commonwealth-State level which really lay at the basis of the failure so far of this community to come to grips with organised crime and official corruption. It is not that knowledge is not somewhere within government agencies. It is that it has not been co-ordinated in a way which allows an effective attack to be mounted. So at the ordinary level we would vest those powers in the authority to act of its own motion.

SPEECH.PARA: However, if it wants to exercise coercive powers, to compel the attendance of persons, to compel answers to questions, to compel the production of documents, to issue search warrants or to require the giving up of passports, it ought to seek a term of reference from an intergovernmental committee. It ought to be able to articulate to some independent body why it needs these extraordinary special powers and governments, by granting terms of reference, ought to accept the responsibility for those extraordinary powers being exercised. For that reason we approve of the idea of an intergovernmental committee, though much reduced in the opportunities it will have for directing the activities of the crime authority. In particular, we say that States ought not to have a power virtually to veto the Commonwealth, in its desire to have the authority carry out some investigation of relevant Commonwealth criminal activity, or States which wish to undertake the services of the authority in investigating some crimes within their borders.

Very briefly, the other major innovation in our report is to say that hearings of the authority ought to be conducted in private out of the public gaze. For that reason the Committee came to the very firm conclusion that the grand jury model of the United States or the ordinary police investigation techniques of Australia, whereby admissible evidence is assembled and then handed to an appropriate person for a decision as to whether proceedings in court should ensue, ought to be conducted in private to safeguard the reputations of persons, their safety and the possibility of their having a fair trial at a future stage, and indeed so that other investigations are not put in jeopardy. For those reasons, we say that such hearings ought to be held in private, out of the public gaze, but that there should be public sittings of the authority during which time it can educate and alert the public to criminal activity and official corruption in Australia. For example, the authority could draw the public's attention to fraudulent tax evasion schemes of which it was aware.

I believe that the worth of the report will be seen in a week or so when the Government brings its Bill into this chamber. It is on the basis of honourable senators reading our report in comparison with the Bill that we will see whether the Government has come up with a viable proposal for passage of legislation. Then, as annual reports are put down by the authority from year to year, this chamber will be able to come to an assessment of the integrity with which the authority is discharging its obligations. Then, of course, when the sunset clause comes into operation, we will have a fuller opportunity to see whether the Senate Committee and the Government, in co-operation, have brought into being a new authority within our community which has discharged the task that we wished to set it; namely, to suppress organised crime and official corruption.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BICENTENNIAL ROAD DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1984ROADS GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to add some comments to the debate on the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill 1984 and the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1984 that are now before the Senate. I believe that road construction-and the money for that purpose, which is the subject of the Bills-is one of the most important problems facing this country. Australia is, of course, a vast continent. A great deal of it is very sparsely inhabited, but people live there just the same. Much of our wealth comes from industries which require the settlement of our far-flung areas . I refer specifically to the mining and rural industries. Because of the nature of those industries small towns are established, often thousands of miles away from anywhere and anything.

SPEECH.PARA: Roads are vital to the communication process in these areas. They not only enable individuals to get on with the business of living but also enable companies to have access to the major ports and business centres to distribute their production. I certainly believe that to disenfranchise the people of these areas, who are the major producers in this country, is to disenfranchise the future of Australia as a viable producer and exporter. Roads are an integral and vital part of our development. I suggest that not enough funds are being allocated to this program. We realise that the people who live in the far outback have to travel long distances and use a lot of fuel. We know that there has been an increase in the price of petrol. That would be quite all right, provided we knew that the revenue gained from the increase in the price of petrol was going towards the building of roads. We know that the revenue gained from indexation of the petrol price in this case has not been put towards the building of roads. We realise that the Australian bicentennial roads program has highlighted the need for better roads throughout Australia. It has set out in a major way to correct this problem. However, I feel that this Government is misdirecting the extra revenue gained from the indexation of the prices, which should be going towards roads and not just to Consolidated Revenue.

As all honourable senators would be well aware, two significant studies on national highways over the past few years have illustrated the serious deficiencies in the funding of highways in this country, and roads, too, for that matter. Some highways are reasonable, but when one gets away from the highways one finds that the roads are rather bad. The problem of road funding has, I believe, really reached an emergency situation in Australia. Largely as a result of the studies conducted, the Fraser Government introduced the bicentennial road development program, which has been the only major road funding initiative to emerge in recent years. I pay tribute to the Hon. Ralph Hunt, who was the Minister for Transport and Construction at the time, because he persuaded Mr Fraser and the Government to go ahead with that scheme. I also mention that, according to the Hon. Russ Hinze of Queensland, he managed to persuade Ralph Hunt to get on with the job and that the need was for money to be set aside.

I think that, for the bicentennial year which is coming up, an improvement in the roads throughout Australia most certainly will be a great achievement. The program has provided impetus to road construction. There is no doubt about it. When one travels by road around Queensland in particular one often sees signs stating that the schemes operating on such roads have been funded by the bicentennial roads program. Of course we need to continue those improvements in the roads. In 1983-84 the ABRD program has bolstered funds to a reasonable level , but not to a level which will reduce the vast backlog of work which is needed to upgrade our major highways. Indeed, in Queensland the concern is not what is being allocated for 1983-84 but what will happen with funds in future years.

Prior to the last election, the then Opposition party, the Australian Labor Party, was vocal in its complaints about the increasing price of petrol. It promised that if it was elected it would reduce the price of petrol by 3c a litre. We know what happened. It did not decrease the price of petrol; it increased it by 2c a litre. Worse still was to come, because it indexed it every six months. Unfortunately, the indexation is not going towards road construction ; it is going to Consolidated Revenue. In other words, it is like an extra tax. It is being used for other purposes. Australian motorists are not happy to put up with paying an increase every six months. Nevertheless, if they felt that the revenue gained from that indexation was going towards the building of roads perhaps they would feel happier at putting up with it. Not only does the money need to go towards the construction of roads but also towards the maintenance of roads. That is also a real problem. I am glad that the Opposition parties will move an amendment during the Committee stage which will indicate that the revenue gained from the indexation should go towards the use of roads and not into Consolidated Revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is to prevent the misappropriation of it.

—That is right. That is exactly what Senator Kilgariff said this morning. It is most important. I will wholeheartedly support the Opposition's amendment. The indexation money is not going towards roads at present. Of course, we know that costs are rising all the time. That means that the ABRD program will be somewhat inadequate and will, I believe, decline sharply.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the current studies of Australian roads will soon be available to the Government. The picture that this study will present will be worse than that shown by the national highway studies. Queensland has special needs because of its vast area and its decentralised population. The total road system in Queensland extends 160,000 kilometres, of which 40,000 kilometres is declared under the State's Main Roads Act. Some of it is in quite bad condition. Much of it is still undeveloped and much of the constructed length is aging. We certainly have so much traffic that a great deal of extra work is needed to cover the growth in the traffic volumes and loadings. The additional needs have arisen from the massive growth in the mining industry, which is vital, of course , to the nation's economy. There are now significant towns in what were very sparsely settled regions of our State. New grain growing areas have opened up and the people growing the grain need reasonable roads to get their grain to the rail. Roads are a vital, important and necessary part of this development and they are vital for the people who live in the areas which are servicing this new growth, a growth which is benefiting all Australians through our increased export earnings.

The Queensland Government and local governments in our State are doing what they can to maintain their share of road funding efforts. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the Queensland Government has twice increased road registration fees, in 1981 and 1984. This year the people of Queensland became somewhat irate because the registration fees were increased by so much. But money to cover the cost of road works must be found, and that is what the Queensland Government was trying to do. The Federal Government, of course, has the major access to finanical resources to solve the road funding problem. I am sorry that, whilst the present Government talks about the need for the ABRD program, it really is not playing fair with the funds that are allocated to road works in this country. In its future planing the Federal Government must provide for a signicant increase in real terms in its total funding allocation from roads grants and ABRD sources. The funds must be directed to the areas of greatest need in the most direct and effective manner through State and local governments which have at their disposal the local knowledge, expertise and all the necessary means of construction and maintenance.

I turn now to clause 5(2) of the Bill, which refers to a change in the tendering system. I can appreciate the value that results from a tendering system for contracts. I suppose it does not matter whether we are building roads , a house or additions or alterations, we would want to get the best possible price and the best possible results. I feel that this tendering system has brought good results, although perhaps not enough of them, because there are so many roads throughout Australia. Nevertheless, the tendering system has proved to be quite beneficial. It is a private enterprise system which creates a lot of employment and it has been working well. I am not sure why there is any need to change the present situation. However, I recognise that in the far outback-not only in Queensland but also in Western Australia, some of the other States and perhaps even in the Northern Territory-in many country towns the construction and maintenance of roads provides valuable employment for people.

I also believe that under the present system local authorities have the opportunity to tender for works. This helps to keep our country towns going. I speak from experience, having travelled around the country for many years. I worked for the Main Roads Commissioner for a number of years, and I had the opportunity to travel around with him. I guess that was in the days before the ABRD program and the roads were not even as good as they are now. Nevertheless, as I travel over the roads at the moment, I realise that there is a need for further money to be made available. Looking through the alterations to the tendering idea, I believe that there are works of such a minor nature that additional cost would be involved if they were put to tender. That could, of course, be a responsibility of the shire. However, I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the amendments to the tendering arrangements give a great discretionary power to the Minister for Transport. I hope that the Minister responsible will be mindful of that power and use it with the knowledge of the real situation and with caution. I would hate to see a situation where a government was more concerned with playing politics than with doing the job which people had elected it to do, and that is to serve their best interests. I certainly cannot stress enough the importance of our national road network. I reiterate that if Australia is to develop and prosper, urgent attention must be given to the increase in funds for the construction of roads and, indeed, for the continued maintenance of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.
