QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 27 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware that the average cost of electricity delivered to New South Wales county councils is 4.5c per kilowatt and that this is greater than the Minister's figure for wind generated electricity in Denmark, given in reply in Senator Cook's question without notice on 2 March 1984.
(2) Is the Minister aware that the southern coastline of Australia is windier than most of Denmark, and hence wind generated electricity in this area may be cheaper than in Denmark.
(3) Will the Minister undertake to re-evaluate the priority of wind energy in his Department in view of these facts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However, the cost per kilowatt hour of electricity from a wind generator depends critically on the wind energy resources at the particular site . As I said on 2 March, the cost figures for wind-generated electricity in Denmark were at the point of production, not the point of delivery; nor did they include an allowance for the cost of additional generating plant required to ensure that electricity is available when there is no wind. The cost of generating electricity from wind in Denmark is not directly comparable with the cost of purchasing electricity generated in New South Wales. I also noted in my reply to Senator Cook that the Danish figures were supplied by manufacturers of the equipment.

(2) Concerning the honourable senator's assertion about wind in Australia and Denmark the fact is that some sites on the southern Australian coastline have good wind energy resources and at others the wind resources are poor. Further investigations are needed to establish the extent of Australia's wind energy resources and the contribution they could make to energy supply. Such studies are being conducted, with support from the national energy research, development and demonstration (NERDD) program, for Tasmania, Lord Howe Island and western New South Wales. In addition similar studies are being carried out in New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia with support from the respective State governments.

(3) Priorities within the NERDD program are reviewed annually and decisions on future priorities for wind energy will take into account the results of the studies I have previously mentioned. In view of the general level of support currently being provided for wind energy by both Commonwealth and State governments. I see no reason to re-evaluate the medium priority accorded to wind energy at present.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 28 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Minister for Resources and Energy expect that the Northern Territory Government will be formally consulted by the Commonwealth at any future stage of the development of the future national uranium policy in view of the recent Commonwealth inquiry which will look at Australia's involvement in the nuclear fuel cycle.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 28 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Could the Minister for Resources and Energy explain whether there is any difference between the risks to the environment posed by the use of fossil fuels or nuclear energy for generation of electricity, in view of a recent announcement made by the New South Wales Minister for Environment of a three- year study on the potential threat of acid rain in the Newcastle-Hunter Valley region; if so, which pathway does the Government believe we should be actively promoting on the international scene, as a nation supposedly oriented towards responsible environment protection policies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The use of fossil fuels and nuclear energy poses different kinds of risk to the environment. Both warrant a significant effort in, firstly, determining the physical and chemical process involved and, secondly, developing techniques to contain potentially polluting substances.

The main pollutants from the combustion of fossil fuels such as coal are oxides of sulphur and nitrogen, which are believed to be the main causes of acid rain. Acid rain is alleged to be a major problem where there is a concentration of power stations emitting high sulphur fumes, which occurs in certain parts of North America and Europe. Australian coals currently used in power stations have a low sulphur content and to date there is no evidence that their use is contributing to an undesirable increase in the acidity of rain in Australia. Nevertheless it is prudent to investigate the current situation and the Government has provided a grant of $256,000 under the national energy research, development and demonstration (NERDD) program towards the cost of acid rain investigations in the Hunter Valley. The commencement of this study was recently announced by the New South Wales Minister for Planning and the Environment. The investigation is intended to determine the chemical characteristics of rainfall in the Hunter Valley and, using this information, to determine whether there is an acid rain problem in the region. The study should help assess the need for increased control of sulphur oxide emission.

With regard to the safe disposal of nuclear waste, Australia is making a major contribution to the international effort on the containment of radioactive waste . The Government is supporting the synroc program, which is aiming at the development of a safe waste immobilisation method. The concept which was developed by Professor A. E. Ringwood at the Australian National University (ANU ), immobilises radioactive waste materials within the crystalline structure of synthetic rock, thereby simulating naturally occurring minerals and allowing the possibility of long-term storage and disposal. The Government has provided, through the NERDD program, a total of over $1.5m to the ANU, the Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC) and Griffith University for research and development of synroc. In addition, the Government has approved an amount of $2. 754m over a three year period for the construction of a non-radioactive pilot plant at the AAEC to demonstrate the production of synroc. The Government also considers international cooperation to be an essential part of the synroc program. A formal agreement for cooperation on radioactive waste management and disposal has been entered into with the United Kingdom Government and a cooperative project on synroc will begin soon.

With regard to the promotion of our energy resources internationally, the sale of Australia's energy resources will depend upon the level of international demand, our capability to meet that demand and Australian Government policies concerning the sale and export of our energy resources.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 2 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister for Resources and Energy advise when the NorthernTerritory is likely to be allowed to proceed with mineral exploration in the area known as Kakadu Stage II.
(2) Is the rationale for Commonwealth control of Northern Territory land no longer valid because of the failure of Aboriginal land claims in more than 90 per cent of Stage II.
(3) Are the Commonwealth arguments for control over another 6000 square kilometres of Northern Territory land at best spurious, in the light of self- government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is a follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The question of whether or not mineral exploration will be permitted within the area known as Kakadu Stage II will be addressed during preparation of the plan of management for the expanded Park. A public notice of the intention to prepare a plan of management due to take effect in 1986 will be issued shortly and public comments sought. The National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 prohibits exploration and mining except in accordance with the plan of management.
(2) The Commonwealth's acquisition of the Stage II area of the Park was for the purpose of establishing a National Park. That objective is still valid.
(3) No. See (2) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 4 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will Australia have full equity in the bauxite development at Aurukun in North Queensland.
(2) Will the bauxite mined at Aurukun be processed in Australia or shipped unprocessed overseas.
(3) Will Australian money be used if the bauxite is processed in Australia.
(4) What price per tonne does the Government estimate the bauxite will sell for .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (3) The Aurukun bauxite deposit is held under Special Bauxite Mining Lease No. 9 issued in 1975 by the Queensland Government to the Aurukun Associates (Billiton Aliminium Australia-66.2/3 per cent and Pechiney Australia- 33.1/3 per cent). Both companies are foreign owned and controlled. At such time as development approval is sought for the project, it will be subject to the Government's foreign investment guidelines.

(2) A feasibility study-completed in 1983-for the establishment of an integrated bauxite/alumina operation at Aurukun indicated the project was presently uneconomic. I am informed that the bauxite at Aurukun is of a lower grade than Weipa bauxite and should the Aurukun project eventually proceed it is envisaged that the bauxite mined would be processed in Australia.
(4) No estimate is available of the price per tonne that the bauxite at Aurukun may eventually sell for.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Fifth International Congress on Mathematical Education

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 March 1984 (Hansard, page 324) Senator Macklin asked me a question without notice concerning a grant to the organising committee of the Fifth International Congress on Mathematical Education. I undertook to provide him with further information on an amount of $5,000 referred to in his question.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

I have been advised by the Special Minister of State, whose Department is responsible for the administration of the grants for international conferences scheme, under which the grant was made, that the amount of the grant to the Fifth International Congress on Mathematical Education will be $17,000. Mr Young 's Department, when it offered the initial grant of $5,000, advised the organisers that the amount was subject to review in the light of the outcome of a separate application for assistance by them to the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. This application was unsuccessful. The Special Minister reviewed the initial grant and decided, on the advice of the Interdepartmental Committee on Grants to International Conferences, to increase it to $17,000. In these circumstances the questions raised by Senator Macklin do not in my view require any further response.
